0003128.eventHeadline: Aberdeen Asset Management PLC, 2014 Earnings Call, Dec 01, 2014
0003128.transcript_text1:
Morning, everyone. Welcome to the annual results analysts' presentation for the year to 30th of September 2014. We'll run through the usual routine. I'll do a few slides, just giving some general remarks, and then hand over to the Bill Rattray, who can go into the figures in more detail.
2014 was obviously a good year for us, I think, in a number of ways: increased scale and diversification from SWIP. Cost synergies from SWIP are ahead of expectations, and the incremental margin is already 50% for the second half. And I can -- and Bill will cover later, it's -- the exit multiple, to use that -- the exit operating margin, if I can use that term, is already at 55%; big year in terms of profit, GBP 490 million; earnings per share, down 4%, but if we hadn't done the SWIP transaction, they would have been down a further 6% at negative 10%. So SWIP was 6% earnings per share positive in the second half; full year dividend of 18p, up 13%. So we've had 10 years of uninterrupted dividend growth and, over the last 5 years, 25% compounded dividend growth; and then net cash at the year-end of over GBP 650 million; and of course, AuM at GBP 325 billion. And I'll show you the flows in a minute, but new business flows, more balanced in the final quarter, and in fact, in the higher-margin equity business, a very sharp improvement, as you'll see.
When you look at this slide, you see the rationale, obviously, for doing the SWIP transaction; Aberdeen, 56%; equities over 80% of our revenues coming from 3 high-margin products and 3 subscale businesses. The merger with SWIP, obviously, as you can see, brings the enlarged group equities down to 33%, but more importantly, in revenues, still at round about the 60% mark coming from equities and the bulk of that still coming from the 3 big products that we have at Aberdeen.
I would -- I thought I'd show you here just -- or we'd show you here just some of the gross new flows so you can see them in isolation. And we split it here, as you can see, on the top graph between equities, fixed income, Aberdeen Solutions and property. And then on the bottom, the bottom graph, we've split it up, the gross new business flows between the legacy Aberdeen business and the SWIP business. So you can see what net new business SWIP is generating.
But I think this is probably the more interesting slide because I think it tells the story of the year better than any figures, I think. What it does show is these massive outflows we had in our emerging market business and our Asian business and our global business in those first 2 quarters, and then we had a big institutional outflow in the third quarter. So as I say, it does show, in stark reality, those massive flows that we had out of the high-margin businesses in the first half of the year, which affected revenue hugely. And then we've seen the sharp improvement in the fourth quarter of the flows within equities, so a big recovery, as I say, in the fourth quarter.
It might be as well just to cover very briefly, before I hand over to Bill, the rationale behind the SWIP transaction. The first one was, obviously, to strengthen the capabilities, as I've already said, fixed income, solutions and properties. And we've -- as you can see here, in the progress, we've restructured the front offices of those 3 divisions. 
The long-term strategic relationship with Lloyds, we're making good progress there and we're seeing very good flows into the property fund. In fact, we're trying to slow flows into the property fund at the moment just because we can't get the money into the market.
And then finally, as always, trying to create value for our shareholders, we've already covered the operating margin of 55%. We've achieved that earlier than we expected, and we expect further synergies in the back office. And then, of course, one of the rationale was financial, additional cash generation to reinforce the progressive dividend policy we have.
So just concluding on my slides before I hand over to Bill. Here, you can see the increase over the last 10 years of earnings per share of less than 5p, 5p earnings per share, up unto this year, where the dividend is 18p per share, so very strong growth in the dividend and earnings per share and, of course, cash generation during that event. I think this slide also portrays one of the things we've said, which is the dividend is not tied to a fixed payout rate. We would expect to see it grow even if, as you see here, earnings per share are marginally down at 4%.
I won't say any more, but hand over to Bill Rattray. I'll even turn the page for you there, Bill, so that you can get off to a flying start.

---

Good morning, everyone. Even better than that, you've covered most of the points on the first slide.
So let me pick on one of the ones you haven't covered is the operating margin. Well, maybe I wasn't listening. 43.9% this year, that's down 1.5% on the last year. Virtually, all of that is down to the lower performance fee income, which, I think, is probably not a great surprise to you. The rest, really, all nets out: the benefit of SWIP, as Martin mentioned, offsetting the reduced profitability from the impact of the equity outflows.
And just doing a reconciliation of how the profit has moved over the year. You can see in the first orange bar the net effect of the earlier part of the year is that management fees from the original Aberdeen business were down by about GBP 48 million. SWIP, of course, coming in from the second half, has boosted that by close to GBP 120 million. And performance fees, you can see in the middle there, close to GBP 30 million, down on last year's record figure. But on the cost side, I mean, those are -- the benefit within the existing Aberdeen business, we were able to trim some costs to react to the lower revenues. On the other side, SWIP coming in has brought in new costs of GBP 60 million. I'll cover that in a little bit more detail in the -- in one of the later slides.
And you're probably fairly familiar by now with this slide. We break the revenues, profits and margin down into discrete half year periods. And you'll see and recall that the first half of this year saw the first real downturn in the margin for some while, but you can see it's bounced back pretty strongly with the benefit of SWIP coming in, in the second half.
Looking at the numbers in a little bit more detail. We've talked about the operating margin, but the costs out of the equation, the compensation ratio is 34.8% for the year. It's a little bit up on last year, but if you look at the historic trend, it's been pretty consistently round about 35% for the few years before that. And I think we did reflect this time last year that probably 33% was a little bit unsustainable. Going forward, I mean, I think the guidance is pretty much what you've heard us say before, somewhere around about 35%, 36%. That sort of order feels like a realistic number. 
In terms of the other costs, you've seen already that we added GBP 60 million in the second half from SWIP. So when you're modeling forward, clearly, you want to add something in for the full year effect of that, but again, just same message as last year. We don't really see any material uptick in the non-staff costs, so just some sort of allowance for indexation.
Then looking at slightly more detail at the SWIP contribution. As Martin's already mentioned, the operating margin from that discrete business in the second half is fractionally short of 50%. And the key to that, as you'll recall, is the cost synergies we expected to achieve from eliminating some duplicate overhead from the business. 
Now as you'll recall, that is something that was happening during the period. So what you're seeing is the actual return for the 6 months. As Martin's already mentioned, if we take a snapshot, the picture, as we exit at the end of September, that margin's already up to 55%. And you'll recall that that's the target we set in the announcement document to get there by September 2015 once the back office is fully integrated. So you can see we're broadly about a year ahead of the game. There's still a little bit more can come out over the next few months, but also, we still have this additional benefit at the end of 2015 when the back office is fully integrated. So you can, I guess, extrapolate that sort of number, and you'll probably come to a figure round about 60% rather than the 55% we guided on.
And just briefly on the revenue side. I mean, a slight change in mix now with SWIP having come in. Performance fees were always a relatively small part of our overall revenues, historically no more than 5% of total revenues. The SWIP business brings very little in the way of performance fee income. So a combination of that and the fact that performance fees were down anyway means that we're now 2% coming from performance fees and, more importantly, 98% from recurring sources. And that's the sort of pattern we'd expect going forward.
The blended fee rate's actually a fairly difficult one to try and explain to you in simple but meaningful terms this time. What I'm going to focus on is the final 2 columns, and you'll recall that the pro forma blend of the Aberdeen and the SWIP business that we mentioned at completion, we expected an overall blended fee rate of round about 36.5 basis points. The actual for the second half of this year is at 36.9, and the comforting thing is that -- is both the Aberdeen and the SWIP elements of the business are slightly ahead of expectations. I think the theme going forwards, you've heard us say it before, is really to be taking new business on at better than the bank books. So the theme is -- very much is to try and get that blended fee rate rising again.
On cash flow, a pretty strong performance, pretty full conversion
[Audio Gap]
just over 110% conversion. We've had the usual few ins and outs in terms of seed capital and other investments
[Audio Gap]
just about GBP 460 million. The way the SWIP transaction was structured, it brought in some cash in the opening balance sheet, some of which we've used to offset the one-off expenses we've incurred so far, but the rest of it was there really to offset the additional regulatory capital requirement. So overall, free cash flow this year was GBP 500 million. We've used GBP 200 million of that to pay last year's final and this year's interim dividends in cash terms and used GBP 65 million to buy the shares required to ensure EBT remains fully vested for deferred shares, so very, very strong increase in cash, GBP 238 million.
And then moving on to regulatory capital. If I start at the bottom line here, you'll recall that when we spoke just after the half year results, the accounting impact of SWIP had knocked a little bit of a dent in the surplus that we had over the regulatory requirement. We've rebuilt that. I mean, the board has been fairly clear they would like to see a buffer of some headroom of around about GBP 100 million over the regulatory requirement, and you can see we've rebuilt that at just around GBP 115 million over.
So a slight change in presentation this time around. You will notice that at the top half of the table, we've deducted the pension surplus that we have in the balance sheet this time around. Previously, we had just included that within the capital requirements, so there's a slight turnaround. But you can see the actual regulatory capital we have at GBP 465 million is comfortably ahead of the GBP 350 million requirement. 
And just to rationalize that GBP 465 million in terms of the cash that Martin's mentioned in the balance sheet, the key thing is when we look at regulatory numbers, we have to make a deduction for the final dividend we propose. So in very round terms, the GBP 650 million of cash, GBP 150 million -- or just short of GBP 150 million for the final dividend, so in round figures, GBP 500 million and a few other minor assets and liabilities in the balance sheet. That is broadly the picture on the GBP 465 million.
So in summary, as Martin mentioned at the start, I mean, really, SWIP -- it's been a strange year. It's been a year of 2 halves, as the saying goes. SWIP has clearly transformed the business, progressing in line with our expected timing, but we're already ahead of the game on cost synergies; strong cash generation and we expect that to continue; and again, as Martin's mentioned, the aim is to keep the dividend rising steadily.
So with that, I'll sit down and open it to questions.

0003128.transcript_text3:
Thanks, Bill. Any questions? Bruce? One at the front here.

---

Yes. Bruce Hamilton, Morgan Stanley. Firstly, given the SWIP deal has obviously gone very well, and you're well progressed on integration. How do you think now about sort of possible further M&A? It seems like there's quite a few potential assets out there. I mean, is there any gaps that you think would be kind of interesting? And then secondly, sorry, a more numbers one, just understanding the SWIP revenue margins in equities and fixed income, it looks like equities went up a lot in the second half and fixed income slightly down. That'd be helpful.

---

I'll let you do the second question. I think we've said it's going to be a further 18 months, the SWIP integration. So really it does take any substantive M&A off the table. I mean, if something came up that was an add-on of a capability we don't have, we'd certainly have a look at it, but certainly nothing substantial. We're committed to generating cash for our shareholders, Bruce. I like the way the people laugh actually.

---

Yes. On the SWIP fee margins, I mean, the equity is one of -- there's actually pretty strange reasons. One of the mandates we lost was pretty low margin. You recall that was a very small book of business anyway. So it really is just that impact. The fixed income one, I suspect is really just a mix effect in we are -- we have been just sort of settling down some of the analysis of what we report actually is fixed income as opposed to what is part of solutions. I suspect it was just an evening out of some of those numbers.

---

It's Arnaud Giblat from UBS. Three questions, please. First, could you perhaps give us a bit more color on the October, November flows, specifically around your equity funds? Also, maybe what consultants might be saying there in terms of performance? Secondly, are you thinking about maybe reopening those funds, taking away the upfront loans? And finally, capital returns. Now that you're in excess of your GBP 100 million target headroom, I'm sure you'll be expecting some capital returns in the longer term.

---

Bill, do you want to cover the first?

---

Right, I'll cover. October, November, looking pretty similar to what you saw for the September quarter; equities, pretty flat. I mean, the 3 main equity classes. GEM is reasonably flat, maybe fractionally negative; Asia Pacific and global equities, both slightly positive; and of course, the wider asset classes mild outflows, but as I say, nothing really different to the September quarter.

---

I think on equity performance, what the consultants are saying is we've seen the recovery from our 2013 underperformance. And if you have a look at page -- I can just barely see the number here, 38, you can see the year-to-date numbers are the key numbers as far as we're concerned and they're broadly in line or outperforming really. The one we're not is probably global equities, where we've been underweight, America, but again, that's sort of explainable. I think the consultants are more worried about to come out -- and this partly answers your question. They're more worried about capacity than they are about performance because we've done what we said we would do on performance really. So I think what it does mean is we can't reopen the global equity funds anytime -- sorry, the Global Emerging Market Funds anytime soon, but we are seeing interest from institutional shareholders. So we can balance really redemptions into taking on new institutional business, but I don't see us reopening the -- or taking the front-end fund or load off the GEM funds.

---

Yes. Capital returns?

---

Oh, capital. Sorry, I almost forgot that. Yes, I mean, I think we've got excess. What we do need, and Bill can maybe cover this, is we do need to have -- what is the word for this, well, they're not audited figures, but they're...

---

Yes. We can only recognize additional increases in that headroom on a half yearly basis when -- either on audited results or from the half year figures are really -- are viewed and published. So the next time we actually show you something in excess of that GBP 100 million headroom, is -- it's going to be the March numbers.

---

So March is when we would expect to see -- and we are committed to buying back equity at that point, once we generate additional cash. If the cash generation's good in this half, there is no reason why we should not see repurchase of shares in the future, plus, of course, good dividend growth as well. Let's not forget the dividend growth. Peter?

---

It's Peter Lenardos from RBC. A couple of quick questions. First of all, I noticed in fiscal '14, you actually sold shares out of your treasury. You had more bought back at the half period than you did at the period end. Just curious why you'd be selling those shares back when you plan to retire shares in the future. And the other question I have is the weakening of the GBP is obviously good for your business. Against what key currency should we measure that?

---

Probably the dollar?

---

Yes, the main one's the U.S. dollar. To a slightly lesser extent but maybe somewhat linked, would be Singapore dollar. I guess, the third one worth mentioning is the euro, which is probably more important within some of the property business.

---

And on the shares?

---

On the shares, I mean, yes, you're right, we ended up -- the EBT ended up with surplus shares at the end of the half year. And we decided because it's a drag on regulatory capital, it was the wrong thing to do to continue to hold that surplus long term. So we turned the position the second half.

---

Yes. I'd see us retire -- canceling shares rather than holding them in the EBT in the future. So they were in the wrong structure basically. There's one there.

---

Arun Melmane, Canaccord. I had a question on the strategic relationship you had with -- or you still have with Lloyds. Where has that gone? Is it still driving some flows? When do you expect that to sort of fire on all engines would be a question.

---

I think the first thing to say is they're very committed to -- at the top level within Lloyds, to making this relationship work at that strategic level. And we're still in the process of working with them on what sort of products will -- would be suitable for more general distribution, shall we say, rather than the wealth area or the private banking area of the bank. And that's where, I think, the -- this capability we have in Quantec with these is going to be really useful because I think the products that banks are now going to look for have got to have low-tracking errors and low cost. So it will be designed around those areas, but they are very committed to this relationship, as you know. And I've given you the statistic before. They have 25% of the current account market in the U.K. and a 2% share of the wealth market, and they really do want to grow that. But as you know, we've got to be very careful what gets sold into any sort of banking market. And you probably saw the announcement at the weekend. They've removed the incentive arrangements for all their branch networks going from the 1st of January. So again, I think that helps. I think it means that they're not going to be pushing products but actually genuinely selling what is suitable for investors in the future.

---

Could we see that later [indiscernible]

---

Yes, I think so. I mean, I think, as we've said, we place very little store by building the relationship on that side. I think the senior management at Lloyds, as I say, are very committed to it, and as far as we're concerned, as you know, it's a deferred arrangement position. So if we do have to pay, we'll have done pretty well as a result of it. It looks like -- oh, one more -- sorry.

---

Sorry, Tom Mills, Crédit Suisse. I just wondered, could you say where -- which products you're seeing client interest in going into 2015?

---

Yes. I think more of the same probably. We are seeing institutional interest in emerging market equities. We're seeing quite a lot of interest in the SWIP property fund. The issue there is getting -- as I've said, getting the money into the market, so we're really having to be quite disciplined on not taking or not pushing the -- pushing that product or pushing that fund too far. We're still seeing quite a lot of interest in the emerging market debt products. I would say that's it. I mean, what we're trying to do is really try and broaden the business away from this huge overreliance we had on these 3 blockbuster products that we're lucky enough to have. So those are the areas we're trying to push, as well as the solutions businesses, trying to get more money into the fund of funds businesses. Yes?

2020459.eventHeadline: Honeywell International Inc., 2015 Guidance/Update Call, Dec 15, 2014
2020459.transcript_text1:
Thank you, Rich. Good morning, and welcome to Honeywell's 2015 Outlook Conference Call. With me here today are Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Tom Szlosek; and Vice President of Investor Relations, Elena Doom. This call and webcast, including any non-GAAP reconciliations, are available on our website at www.honeywell.com/investor. 
Note that elements of this presentation contain forward-looking statements that are based on our best view of the world and of our businesses as we see them today. Those elements can change, and we'd ask that you interpret them in that light. 
We identify the principal risks and uncertainties that affect our performance in our Form 10-K and other SEC filings.
This morning, we will review our financial expectations for the remainder of 2014 and discuss our 2015 planning, building on the framework we gave you back in October, and of course, we'll allow time for your questions. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Tom Szlosek.

---

Thanks, Mark, and good morning, everyone. Let's begin on Slide 3 by confirming the fourth quarter is on track with about 2 weeks left in the year. We are exiting 2014 with strong momentum, evidenced by a continuation of positive short-cycle order rate trends and a robust backlog in our long-cycle businesses. We are reaffirming our full year 2014 pro forma EPS guidance of $5.50 to $5.55 a share, up 11% to 12% versus 2013. We continue to expect organic sales growth of approximately 3% for both the fourth quarter and the full year. 
As I'm sure you've seen by now in our press release, we sold the remaining 1.9 million of BEAV shares in the fourth quarter and are deploying the gain to fund certain Aerospace OEM incentives. I'll walk through all the details in a moment, but wanted to reiterate that the transactions have no impact on our fourth quarter net income, EPS or free cash flow guidance and position Aero well for future growth with the biggest impacts on 2016 and 2017. 
Looking ahead, 2015 is poised to be another terrific year for Honeywell. We have and will continue to invest in R&D and sales and marketing resources globally. This focus on innovation has enabled big wins in the marketplace. There are many examples that we have shared with you throughout the year, and they pervade our entire portfolio. Our penetration in the high-growth regions is relentless, and we continue to drive CapEx investments in high ROI projects, particularly in PMT. 
While expecting to achieve double-digit free cash flow growth, we are also investing in CapEx at a rate approximately 1.5x to 2x depreciation, a trend we expect to continue into 2015. We've also been able to proactively fund restructuring projects, and we're expecting over $140 million for the full year of 2014, which allows us to drive sustainable productivity action. 
The Honeywell enablers continue to result in growth and operational excellence across the company. Key initiatives like Velocity Product Development, Organizational Effectiveness and Functional Transformation are resulting in significant benefits across the portfolio, and we are broadening our approach to HOS Gold. You'll remember that our focus for HOS was first on the supply chain and then to our product development process. That initiative has paid off well, and we are now applying HOS Gold across all business processes in our 70 HOS Gold enterprises, which will enable and sustain exceptional growth and productivity improvements. We are excited to share more about this at our March Investor Day. 
Today, we'll provide an update on the markets we serve and a bottom-up portfolio view that supports our 2015 outlook. Our plans reflect a modest growth environment. So we have once again been conservative on cost assumptions. We've also incorporated the impacts from the stronger U.S. dollar. For example, you will see that we have planned the euro at $1.20. We feel confident that with our balanced portfolio mix, alignment to favorable macro trends, focused growth initiatives and cost discipline, we'll continue to outperform. 
I'm now on Slide 4, which presents a brief recap of the BEAV share gains and deployment actions, which will yield benefits in 2015 and beyond, principally in 2016 and 2017. You will recall that we've divested the Consumables businesses --  the Consumables Solutions business to B/E Aerospace in 2008. At the time, we received cash proceeds of $900 million plus 6 million shares of BEAV common stock with a fair value at the time of roughly $150 million. We sold 2.6 million shares in the fourth quarter of 2013 and 1.5 million shares in the first quarter of 2014. We sold the final 1.9 million shares in the current quarter. The timing of this last sale was important from a tax perspective. The timing allowed us to offset the gain with other items, minimizing the tax on foreign earnings. So the total realized value of the share consideration to Honeywell was $500 million, a nice upside compared to that $150 million basis in the stock. For each of the 3 lots that we sold, we have developed -- we have deployed the resulting gains for restructuring and other actions that proactively position the company for future growth and profitability. In this fourth quarter, the gains will be fully offset on an after-tax basis by a recognition of the cost of providing certain commercial OEM incentives. We have one significant content in the Air Transport and Business Aviation sectors, including 737 MAX, 777X, E2, A320neo, A330neo and a number of unannounced wins. The incentives become required in the fourth quarter when our customer achieves certain contractual milestones in platform development, which will include Honeywell avionics and/or mechanical content. 
In the lower-left section of Page 4, you can see that there is very little tax on the $116 million pretax gain from the BEAV share sales. This reflects the tax planning that I mentioned. So the net after-tax gain is $114 million. Offsetting the gain is our recognition of $184 million of OEM incentives, which, after incorporating the tax benefit, will be a $114 million charge. 
On a net-of-tax basis then, these 2 items fully offset one another; no impact to EPS for the quarter or full year as a result. The tax benefit will end up lowering Honeywell's estimated effective tax rate for the quarter to 25.6% and the full year to approximately 25.7%. 
The P&L geography of the 2 items deserves some explaining because the cost for the OEM incentives is included in the Aerospace segment as a reduction of revenue, whereas the gain from the sale of the BEAV shares is not included in the Aerospace segment. 
I'll talk more about that in a minute on the next slide, but just to close on this slide, I want to point out that these actions will significantly benefit Aerospace over our Five-Year Plan and beyond. We believe that we're well positioned for future success with our commercial OE customers, as highlighted earlier, and there will continue to be OEM incentives reflected by Aero going forward consistent with that business model, but based on the current book of business, the future year-over-year impact of these incentives should be minimal. 
Let's turn to Page 5 where we will preview what the fourth quarter financials are expected to look like with the inclusion of the gain and its deployment to fund the Aero OEM incentives. On the left in the column labeled prior guidance, you see the fourth quarter 2014 guidance that we shared with you in October. And on the right is our revised outlook reflecting the impacts I just discussed. 
Let me first call your attention to the last 2 lines, net income and EPS. In both cases, there is no impact to our outlook for Q4. 
So back to the top, starting with sales. We present the impact of $184 million OEM incentives on the reported fourth quarter 2014 growth for both Honeywell in total and the Aerospace segment itself. The $184 million of OEM incentives will be recorded as a reduction in revenue, and so the reported Honeywell sales growth guidance is now down 2% compared to 2013. Just to remind you, this treatment is consistent with our approach of not burdening our balance sheet, and therefore, subsequent earnings with capitalization of upfront incentives provided to customers. In contrast, many of our peers capitalize OEM incentives and depreciate the cost over the life of the projects. We believe charging the incentive costs upfront gives greater transparency to our OEM profitability in this segment. 
The important takeaway on the sales line here is that while there are small puts and takes in individual businesses, there is no change to our organic sales growth guidance. We continue to forecast approximately 3% organic growth for Honeywell in total and approximately 2% organic growth for Aerospace. 
The change to the Aero segment margin outlook is also $184 million. The revenue impact we noted flows to segment profit. And as a result, for the fourth quarter, we now anticipate 20 basis points of margin contraction for Honeywell in total and 130 basis points of margin contraction in Aero, again however, no change to the underlying performance of the business. 
Moving to the impact outside of segment profit or below the line. We've shown the $116 million pretax gain from the sale of the remaining BEAV shares as well as the $68 million net tax benefit, primarily from the Aero OEM incentives. You can see that the $184 million reduction from our previous segment profit guidance is fully offset by the gain on sale of the shares and the associated tax benefits. So when you net the impacts of these 2 items, the impact to net income is 0. We remain on track to our pro forma EPS guidance of $1.37 to $1.42, up 10% to 15% from 2013, representing another quarter of double-digit earnings growth. As a reminder, this excludes any mark-to-market adjustment related to our pension plans. 
Based on current interest rates and year-to-date asset returns, we do not expect a material mark-to-market adjustment to our U.S. plans in the fourth quarter, but there likely will be a mark-to-market adjustment in our international pension plans. You'll recall that this amounted to about $51 million in 2013. At this time, we're currently expecting it to be in the range of $300 million to $400 million on a pretax basis in the fourth quarter of 2014. 
So before turning our attention to the outlook for 2015, I want to briefly summarize what we're expecting for the full year of 2014. I am on Slide 6. For the year, we're estimating sales to be up approximately 3% on both a reported and organic basis. The updated sales range of $40.1 billion to $40.2 billion reflects the impact from the $184 million Aero OEM incentives I just discussed. Order rates continue to be healthy as we exit the year, building good momentum into 2015. We're also expecting another record year for segment margins driven by commercial excellence and strong productivity benefits across the portfolio. 
Margins are expected to be 16.6% on a reported basis or 17% excluding the Aero OEM incentives. The 17% represents an improvement of 70 basis points versus 2013. This margin expansion is translated into strong EPS growth. Pro forma EPS is expected to be in the range of $5.50 to $5.55, up 11% to 12% from 2013. So when looking at Honeywell's performance over the last 5 years, we grew pro forma earnings double digits every year at a compounded rate of 16%. And once again, we stuck by our earnings outlook all year in 2014, increasing the low end of our range 3 times to reflect the strong year-to-date performance. 
Finally, free cash flow is expected to be approximately $3.9 billion, up about 15% versus 2013 despite an approximate 15% increase in CapEx investments in the areas we have previously described, notably in PMT. 
So with the end of the year in sight, we feel good about how we're exiting the year and the implications for 2015. 
I'm now on Slide 7. We're showing the expected GDP growth by region in real terms for both 2014 and 2015, probably not new information for most of you but something worth quickly reviewing. I think, I mean, from a spares perspective, good growth everywhere. I'd highlight APAC and EMEA on the ATR side. From a BGA perspective, it's the same thing, EMEA and APAC. And when I say EMEA, I'm including the Middle East. They're pretty strong for us in both cases on the spares side. R&O, pretty much similar across-the-board, nothing that stands out. And maybe a little bit more in the Americas, but -- on the BGA side. But other than that, it's been -- it's consistent with the composite growth rate I mentioned.

---

I would just maybe add, Tom, that the U.S. had pretty significant growth in spares in ACR in 2014. So that is going to look to moderate. But as Tom said, it's offset by some uptick in R&O.

---

Talk about legacy liabilities for a moment. Tom, you've done a nice job of moderating them. Where do you see them going? And what other initiatives do you have underway to put those behind you?

---

Yes. I mean, when you look at environmental year-over-year, it'll be -- most of the -- those below-the-line items, between environmental and asbestos, it will be flat -- flattish, slightly down. So we're not going to see any one, single, large decrement in any given year. I think you're going to see us continue to manage those areas such that we experience a gradual decline.

---

And that's on the P&L, right?

---

Right. P&L line.

---

And cash as well? Is that the same way? Or I mean, you seem to have been able to put off some of the funding for the trust or manage it very effectively. Could you just elaborate there for a moment?

---

Yes, I would say that the -- we've had very little 2014 in terms of expenditures relating to the trust. It's still in that formation, infancy stage. And there continue to be some delays in getting it operational. So at some point, you're going to see the cash flows from that NARCO piece jump off. We've planned for more in 2015 on NARCO side, but it's still manageable and within the balance of the $4.4 billion that we mentioned.

---

And then most of your cash continues to be overseas. How are you thinking about managing that relative to what you expect either in terms of taxes or in terms of funding acquisitions?

---

Yes. Well, certainly, we -- there is no intention to, at this current point, to repatriate any of our foreign earnings under the current U.S. tax system. And there's not a lot we can do on that front. We stay active in just monitoring legislation. We are all for a comprehensive tax reform, one that allows for free mobility of capital by U.S. businesses so -- and we're not counting on anything rather than what we have today. We're not counting on any kind of onetime repatriation, for example. So what we do, do is we do 2 things. One is, from a tax-planning perspective, we try and move as much of that foreign cash in the U.S. on a tax-effective basis as is possible. Our tax team and the businesses have that front and center, and we strive to move cash on a regular basis. It's a -- they're modest amounts. I mean, they're less than $0.5 billion in any given year, but there's a lot of activity around that. And of course, we talked about M&A earlier. Certainly, one of our priorities would be to deploy that overseas cash in a way that enables us to take advantage of it from an M&A perspective.

---

I appreciate that. And then, last, to go back to the $184 million. If there's some way that you might be able to help us understand the -- either the competitive dynamic that you achieved by doing this or maybe the potential business revenues that you captured as a consequence of making these investments.

---

Yes. I mean, the most important benefit from the whole thing, Howard, is the continued wins with our OEM customers, both on the ATR and BGA side. Beyond that, we don't talk about specific returns. And I would also think of this one as timing of some milestones that we're accelerating. And we've been able to find a way to take into account and offset the acceleration with the BEAV gains as we talked about. So the Five-Year -- overall Five-Year Plan, we're highly confident, and this really helps us to manage the level of OEM incentives over that 5-year time frame, in particular in 2016 and '17.

---

Yes. [indiscernible].

---

Just a couple cleanup questions here, the first is on the currency hedging. Tom, you said it's 50% of Transportation Systems. Are -- where are the offsets for those hedges? Will that be in corporate? And will you call those out?

---

The offsets -- well, first of all, just to make sure we're on the same page on the 50%. It's 50% of Honeywell's total exposure to the euro, which is all in Transportation Systems. So the impact that you will see from the -- from both the currency depreciation and the offsetting hedge will be in the Transportation Systems business.

---

And how do you pick 50% as the right number just given expectations for further strengthening of the dollar?

---

That's a good question, Deane. When you look at the way we're diversified across Europe and other places outside the U.S., we've got quite a number of locations, each with their own exposure. The largest and most concentrated exposure for us was in Transportation Systems. So it was easy -- easier for us to get at an aggregate chunk of exposure and address it quickly. That's not to say that we're not looking at the rest. So as we close out 2014, we could very well look at some further expansion of that.

---

And then just lastly, on CapEx. If I look back from a year ago, were there any projects that were either pushed out into 2015 or delayed? And then can you comment on expected ROIs? You bragged about some really pretty impressive ROIs in some of the projects in PMT. Could you update those too, please?

---

Yes. Certainly, on the ROIs, they're well accretive to the Honeywell's ROI, I get to start by sharing that. Yes, most of the -- I'd say most of the projects are on schedule in UOP. We've got significant expenditures on -- in the hydro processing catalysts and in other catalysts side, and we've got significant processing -- or significant CapEx on the solstice molecules that we talked about. If there have been any delays, they've been minor and probably focused more on the solstice side than anything else, but they're manageable and there's no revenue at risk in any case on these.

---

Just a question on emerging markets. Your forecast shows slowing in China, yet you have acceleration in your high-growth region revenue. Could you just hit what are the high points that drive this acceleration in the face of slowing China?

---

Yes, I mean, the -- for us, the growth in ACS -- we'll see good growth in China in ACS.

---

In aggregate, maybe actually a little bit ahead on a full year basis in '15 than what we saw in 2014.

---

Yes, right, exactly, yes. But overall, for China -- and I'd say we'll be high single digits. We're forecasting high single digits across the portfolio. It's probably a little less than that this year. And our growth has been a little bit diluted by some intentional movement of some capacity in Resins & Chemicals outside of China into other parts of Asia. So that's kind of diluted down the 2014 growth. In '15, like I said, high single digits. And I would say each of the businesses looks to be in that same range. No distinction between any of the SBGs, so Aero, ACS and PMT. Individual pieces of them have some puts and takes. But overall, pretty strong.

---

I got you. And just one more follow-up question. In terms of your forecast for oil for the year, do you have an explicit forecast that sort of goes into your model for the year?

---

We're not in the business of forecasting oil. We tend to rely on what the external benchmarks would tell you. But no, I don't have a specific forecast for oil.

---

But as we just look at -- what should I look at? The forward curve? Where should I look to get a sense of what are those you use to create the framework for 2015?

---

Well, in terms of the UOP and HPS businesses, Andrew, we're fully looking at the backlog. And as you know, the backlog in PMT in those 2 businesses is up at record levels. The order rates year-to-date have been in double digits and have continued through November and into December. So it's -- we're not trying to hold ourselves or index at all to oil. We're trying to be aware of it. We're trying to look at the backlog and understand where there could be impacts from oil. But like I said, there's been nothing that impacts this in the health of those portfolios in 2015 at this point.

---

Okay. Thank you. Appreciate everyone attending. Just want a reminder that we'll be around all day for everyone's questions.

【質問: Steven Winoker (Analysts)】
Just a couple of questions here. First, the annual operating plan process, I guess, would have largely concluded, although I know it's iterative, maybe right in the middle of oil coming down. And the slide you provided is very helpful, but I'm a little confused in terms of your commentary. You said that we factored in the impact of low oil prices, but you also talked about how there really isn't much impact at all this year anyway. So how did that kind of play out in terms of your bottom-up assessment of the impact?

---

【回答: Thomas Szlosek (Executives)】
Yes, Steve, the most direct impact is on the Resins & Chemicals business. As you know, the inputs to that business are -- the cost inputs of that business are highly correlated to oil. And the contracts in that business, a large portion of the contracts in that business, have price adjustments for the raw material inputs. So you end up seeing an impact on the top line. But what really had served us well is that the way the adjustments work and the way the formulas work, the operating income itself is generally preserved. So that's the major impact that we've reflected. By the way, Steve, that's -- sales-wise, that's probably $115 million or so.

---

【質問: Steven Winoker (Analysts)】
Okay. Well, if you're giving me the sales -- and then what would the bottom line impact be?

---

【回答: Thomas Szlosek (Executives)】
Well, I mean, we don't disclose the profit in those individual segments. But it would be -- it would not be impacted materially in any way by the price of the oil.

---

【質問: Steven Winoker (Analysts)】
Okay. And then another point on that slide, you talked about the downstream, basically positive impact. But how are you guys talking about things like the $32 billion Petronas project that was canceled in Canada or deferred. Some of those activities and actions, internally are you guys looking at that and just saying that's a one-off and actually this is still going to be more positive for us downstream?

---

【回答: Thomas Szlosek (Executives)】
Yes, well, I mean, first of all, we were not a participant on that Petronas project. And -- but we continually assess the impact of oil on our backlog in both HPS and UOP. And as I said and I've tried to emphasize, not seeing anything in terms of delays or cancellations relating to the oil. And actually, some of those projects, like on the LNG side, they continue to provide some future order growth opportunity that we're pretty excited about.

---

【質問: Steven Winoker (Analysts)】
Okay, all right. And maybe I'll just sneak one in before I hand off, but just on the capital deployment front, you talk about share count flat for 2014 levels. You've obviously got peak year on CapEx as you mentioned. But are you -- is the -- the M&A side, you now have been -- Roger has been at it for a little while now. Is part of your thinking on the buyback side kind of placeholder for M&A? And is that driving that commentary around just holding buybacks flat? Or is there something more at this point?

---

【回答: Thomas Szlosek (Executives)】
Yes. Well, if you recall, back with our Five-Year Plan that we went through in March, our intention is that, from an overall capital deployment perspective is to return about half of the cash flow that we generate to shareowners in the form of dividends and share buybacks with the share buybacks coming on an opportunistic basis, the dividends increasing faster than earnings, and you'll note that we increased our dividends in the fourth quarter by 15%. So it should be a good signal for what our expectations are going forward on earnings. As far as the other half of the capital deployment, we reinvest that in the business. You know the piece that's --  the CapEx piece, and we've talked about the $10 billion in M&A. And so over the 5 years, we do expect to deploy that capital, and it could even [ph] be more. But we're -- we have a pipeline. It's active as you mentioned. Starting in April of this year, Roger in his Vice Chairman role, one of his primary responsibilities now is M&A and really trying to engage the other SBGs the way he did it in ACS, and we're starting to see an impact. I mean, the pipelines are pretty strong, and the organization, we've actually doubled down on our resources in the M&A organization itself. So while I can't share any specific details, we do feel like we're making good progress there.

---

【質問: Joseph Ritchie (Analysts)】
So Tom, really helpful to get that oil and gas slide in there. Just a question, it seems like you've got some good visibility on your 2015 growth. But how do you think about what's in your backlog today for '16 and beyond? And is there any risk from prior history that anything in your backlog today gets repriced or revalued?

---

【回答: Thomas Szlosek (Executives)】
Yes. I mean, when you look at the more significant parts of our backlog, I talked about UOP and HPS. And I feel like the -- we're largely intact there, as I said. We're not seeing much of an impact. I mentioned that the Defense & Space backlog is actually up 8% since the beginning of the year, and that is a reflection of the nice progress the team has had in international, in particular. And then in terms of ACS, it's holding intact. So I feel like the 2015 is well positioned. As you know, the backlog diffusion varies by business in terms of when we actually see the impacts in subsequent periods. I mean, for example, Aerospace backlogs tend to show up in the P&L a little bit longer period -- over a longer period than, say, UOP and HPS. But the patterns that we've experienced in the past in terms of the expectations has not changed at all. So we think we're still in a similar mode.

---

【質問: Joseph Ritchie (Analysts)】
But I guess, just specifically, as it relates to UOP or in PMT, is there any risk that, that backlog gets repriced?

---

【回答: Thomas Szlosek (Executives)】
I guess there could be a risk of that. But when you consider the positioning of where we are, when you look at where the exposure in that portfolio is, we have very little in terms of the upstream. And a lot of the upstream pressure that we're seeing on the oil prices is showing up in the higher-cost producers that have -- that are highly leveraged. And so we don't have very much in terms of exposure to that space. And as I said, where we are exposed in that space, we feel like the customer base is well capitalized and has a strong cost position. When you look at the significant -- the more significant part of the portfolio or the majority of the portfolio is in mid and downstream. And you could see how refiners are doing. You could see how petrochemical facilities are doing. It's boding well so far. And past -- our past experience, we've looked at this a little bit, and the PMT team is confident that this is an overall positive on that front.

---

【質問: Joseph Ritchie (Analysts)】
Okay. And maybe if I could sneak one more in on the margins, it seems like nice step-up in margins on the PMT business this year. You've got a tailwind from price/raw mix and then also the facilities coming online. Is there any chance you can give us a little bit more detail on how much of an impact you're getting from price/raw in '15?

---

【回答: Thomas Szlosek (Executives)】
Yes, I would say the -- when you look at -- I mean, as you know, in Resins & Chemicals and in floorings, we've experienced some pressures from price/raws significantly, that moderates in 2015. I don't want to put an exact number on it, but range-wise, it will provide modest improvement in the margin rates in PMT.

---

【回答: Elena Doom (Executives)】
Is it fair, Tom, to say off of the reported conversion rate, that it would be implied in the guidance as higher because of the impacts from the lower sales in R&C related to oil?

---

【回答: Thomas Szlosek (Executives)】
Yes.

---

【回答: Elena Doom (Executives)】
So if you the stretch that out, the conversion rate would be probably in that 35% range.

---

【回答: Thomas Szlosek (Executives)】
And when you consider that and the FX and the Aero OEM, yes, that -- the conversion works exactly like we thought, yes.

---

【質問: Scott Davis (Analysts)】
I'm glad you're confident on oil and gas because the rest of us are a little nervous, so hopefully you're right. But is there a point though -- did you stress test the impact of $50 oil versus $58 or $45 oil? I mean, is there a point where your PMT guys say, okay, bets are all off, like there's going to be a bigger impact here?

---

【回答: Thomas Szlosek (Executives)】
Yes, I mean, we have stress tested. We feel like between -- down to about $50, the 2015 plan, including all the backlog that we have, should be good. We're not, in this fourth quarter, we're not seeing any change to the expected order growth rates despite the prices that we've seen, Scott. So right now, between stress testing and the current -- the most current business, we feel like it's manageable.

---

【質問: Scott Davis (Analysts)】
Okay. I won't beat the dead horse. And then the one thing I thought was a little surprising when I saw the slide is that you expect your share count to be flat. With the cash you're generating, the balance sheet base you have, I would have thought, if you believe this guidance, your stock is pretty darn cheap. I mean, what's the -- I guess -- again getting to thresholds, I mean, what is the point on a stock price or a correction in the S&P that you start to say, hey, we need to change the plan here? Or is just share buybacks off the table completely?

---

【回答: Thomas Szlosek (Executives)】
Yes, I think the way we're talking about deploying the capital, Scott, is not inconsistent with what we said in the Five-Year Plan, and we feel like the best returns that we can generate and provide right now are on the M&A side and our models for the deals that we're looking at continue to support that. And I would say that if there's -- if we go by a significant period of time and we haven't seen activity that supports that $10 billion run rate over the 5-year basis, maybe you'd see us take a different tack. But kind of right now, Dave's view is that's the direction he wants to go in.

---

【質問: Scott Davis (Analysts)】
Okay, fair enough. And then just quickly, I'll sneak one in. I mean, when you talk about the margin tailwind, which has really been a great story for you guys for quite some time now, but what -- is it possible to separate at the impact of HOS and what impact that has directly on margins? And what I mean is not HOS necessarily holistically, but the rate of change in gold versus Silver and silver versus bronze year-over-year. Is that possible to think about that now?

---

【回答: Thomas Szlosek (Executives)】
I mean, it's a little bit tough. The productivity that comes just in the supply chain itself tends to be around conversion costs as well as in areas like cost of poor quality, so warranty, defects, rework, scrap. And so we can look at those individual categories. But I'd say, overall, you have to look at the confluence of the impacts from OEF, the impacts from Functional Transformation, impacts from HOS Gold is all showing up in restructuring. We don't isolate it to just HOS Gold. It comes from all the factors I mentioned.

【質問: Nigel Coe (Analysts)】

【回答: Thomas Szlosek (Executives)】
Nothing significant other than the -- there's a little bit of that Resins & Chemicals impact in the fourth quarter as you would expect. But we've got other offsets in other parts of the portfolio. So net-net, not a significant difference from what we would have shared in October.

【質問: Nigel Coe (Analysts)】

Think I said 9%. Did I?

【回答: Elena Doom (Executives)】
I think we said towards high single digit.

【回答: Thomas Szlosek (Executives)】
Yes.

【質問: Nigel Coe (Analysts)】

【質問: Nigel Coe (Analysts)】
And right now, would you expect that to have a P&L impact or a cash impact?

---

【回答: Thomas Szlosek (Executives)】
It shouldn't have a cash impact. And from a P&L perspective...

---

【回答: Elena Doom (Executives)】
Yes, it's going to be -- with the quarter capacity that we have in the U.S. on the MTM piece, it would have likely no impact.

【質問: Jeffrey Sprague (Analysts)】
Just a couple quick things. Tom, on CapEx, can you actually give us the dollar number and how much you expect it to decline in '16 given that '15 is the top here?

【回答: Thomas Szlosek (Executives)】
Yes, I guess I'd put it in the range of our history, Jeff. We've generally been in the $800 million to $900 million range before we started ramping up. We'll get to about $1.3 billion in 2015. So I would say somewhere between those 2 endpoints is where I would expect to see it on an ongoing basis.

【質問: Jeffrey Sprague (Analysts)】
So you won't get down that far in '16. No, you're not saying...

【回答: Thomas Szlosek (Executives)】
No, no, no. Yes, '15 and '16 will be -- still be -- it'll be $1.1 billion in '14, probably $1.3 billion in '15. '16 will come down a little bit but not materially. Then you start to see it in 2017 and beyond.

【質問: Jeffrey Sprague (Analysts)】
Is R&D up in 2015 in dollars or percent of sales?

---

【回答: Thomas Szlosek (Executives)】
As a percentage of sales, it will be slightly up. We're still around that 5%, call it, 4.9% for 2014, 5.1% for 2015.

【質問: Jeffrey Sprague (Analysts)】

【回答: Elena Doom (Executives)】
There's margin expansion across the entire portfolio, Jeff, in 2015. So UOP -- remember, UOP margins were down in 2014, so they get a nice lift in 2015. 【質問: Jeffrey Sprague (Analysts)】
Okay. And then just one quick one, just back to kind of a share repurchase question. In October, the stock spent a couple weeks in the 80s and actually hit a 52-week low. I mean, did that entice any interest in stepping up a little bit on repo?

【回答: Thomas Szlosek (Executives)】
Yes, like I said, we didn't really view that as the most effective way of using our capital even at that time. Of course, we look at the share price every day, and we take it into account. We're not ignoring it blindly, but we're looking at it from a long-term basis.

【回答: Thomas Szlosek (Executives)】
Yes. Well, I mean, we're not in a position really to talk about the individual commercial arrangements. 【質問: C. Stephen Tusa (Analysts)】
I got it. So there was a -- there's kind of a timing element here where you kind of chose to take these offsets?

---

【回答: Thomas Szlosek (Executives)】
Yes. And it's -- just to emphasize, it has very little impact on 2015. This is more of a Five-Year Plan kind of thing.

---

【質問: C. Stephen Tusa (Analysts)】
But again, this wasn't something that, hey, came up in fourth quarter and you go in and sell some stock. I mean, this is a kind of planned, opportunistic type of dynamic is what I'm hearing?

【回答: Thomas Szlosek (Executives)】
Yes, I mean, it is -- the amounts become due as our customers reach certain milestones. 【質問: C. Stephen Tusa (Analysts)】
Got it. And is this a new development? I mean, obviously, Boeing has talked a lot about partnering for success. And is this -- without that, would there still be these types of incentive payments?

【回答: Thomas Szlosek (Executives)】
No. I would say, Steve, that all of our OEMs have their own moniker that they apply to their productivity initiatives with their suppliers. 【質問: C. Stephen Tusa (Analysts)】
Right. I'm sure you guys have a different moniker. One last question, on Slide 13, below-the-line stable pension upside offset by restructuring, any real change there with those -- maybe some magnitude around those?

【回答: Thomas Szlosek (Executives)】
Yes. I think I said when I was going through it ...

【質問: C. Stephen Tusa (Analysts)】
I'm sorry, if you said it, then don't worry about it. I'll look it up. I missed it then. Not a big deal. I don't want to waste any of your time.

【回答: Thomas Szlosek (Executives)】

【回答: Elena Doom (Executives)】
Yes. [indiscernible].

In aggregate, maybe actually a little bit ahead on a full year basis in '15 than what we saw in 2014.

Thank you, Scott. I'd like to provide more color to accompany the guidance data we provided the market earlier this afternoon. Working our way down the income statement for 2015, we plan to operate inside our 67% to 70% gross margin business model. We are guiding 68% for the year, an improvement from our experience in 2014. The dominant driver for the improvement is more favorable vertical mix versus 2014. We see strength in several sub-vertical markets, which carry higher than corporate average gross margins. By way of background across our 11 sub-verticals, we experience a wide range of gross margins, largely as a result of the differences in the volume at which customers purchase our FPGAs in a given vertical market. Despite the good growth of 2014, the vertical mix of that growth came with pressure to gross margins. We are forecasting a 2015 that has broader and more balanced growth across vertical markets and will therefore carry more typical gross margins. Gross margin will improve through fiscal 2015. 
We're planning operating expenses to grow 2.7% to $760 million in 2015 from $740 million in 2014. R&D will increase 2.6% while SG&A will grow 2.8%. SG&A OpEx will be leveled through the year while R&D will be somewhat first half loaded. 
As we articulated in November 2013, for the next several years, we're striving to increase revenue at a higher rate than OpEx allowing operating margin expansion. 
A few smaller items in passing. Net interest expense is likely to drop as we are repositioning our investment portfolio, thus generating an improved return. Our effective tax rate for 2015 should be 13% to 14% excluding any discrete items. 
Finally, as a result of sustained share repurchases, we see fewer shares outstanding. 
Stepping back, you can see that we have tremendous operating leverage in our P&L moving into the 2015 fiscal year. Gross margin improvement of about 1 point, a very modest increase in OpEx, some savings and other expense and fewer diluted shares outstanding. 
FY '15 will be a year where percentage growth in revenue will create a much larger EPS percentage growth because of this operating leverage. 
With respect to returning cash to shareholders. We are maintaining a 60% to 80% range of return of cash flow from operating activities in 2015 through a combination of dividends and share repurchases. On the repurchase side, we will exit 2014 with funds remaining from $1 billion in debt we raised toward the end of 2013. We'd expect to use those remaining funds in the early part of 2015. 
With respect to the dividend, which is a regular and significant portion of the return of cash, we remain committed to increasing it over time. 
With that, let me turn the call over to John.

---

Thank you, Ron. FPGAs remain well positioned to grow in the years ahead. Rising development costs are limiting the role for fixed function custom ASICs and ASSPs. Simultaneously, Altera FPGAs, staying on Moore's Law, have become more feature-rich with improved performance and lower cost per unit of logic. For customers in infrastructure markets, with the need to create differentiated systems, FPGAs have become more and more essential. At the same time, there is an emerging role for FPGAs as hardware accelerators that offers an additional growth avenue for us. As data centers are deployed in support of cloud computing, Big Data analytics, search and other high-performance computing applications, operators are faced with the challenge of providing a higher performance compute capability yet doing so within an acceptable power budget. The massively parallel structure of FPGAs offers a solution with fast performance, low power and flexibility. Now with the arrival of OpenCL, a software platform easily used by software engineers to target FPGAs as coprocessors, Altera has uniquely removed the biggest engineering barrier to wide-scale adoption of our FPGAs in these acceleration roles. We estimate the accelerator market as a $1 billion TAM by decade's end. 
Our mid-range Arria 10 family and our high-end 14-nanometer FinFET Stratix 10 family are doing very well. Arria 10 is sampling now and has best-in-class performance. Stratix 10, with a new high-performance HyperFlex architecture, is in the software early access phase. Here, Stratix 10 customers have the ability to see for themselves the 2x performance, 4x logic boost and reduced power consumption of this high-end family that will begin shipping in 2015. A record opportunity pipe exists for both families. Additionally, we have identified more than a $0.5 billion of new Stratix 10 opportunities in the telecom and wireless space that previously was beyond the reach due to size, speed, power limitations. 
Stepping back a bit, the R&D investments over the last few years are varied and potent. OpenCL, as I just mentioned, to speed the penetration of our FPGAs as hardware accelerators; plus HyperFlex, our new high-performance, high-density FPGA fabric; plus embedded microprocessors as an option across nearly all of our FPGAs; plus the industry's only FPGA with hardened, embedded, floating-point engine to address the most challenging higher end computational needs; plus the world's first 14-nanometer FinFET based FPGA; plus a new ultra low-end FPGA family in MAX 10; and much more. All of these capabilities are now in place, allowing us to slow the rate of growth of R&D in the coming years, not just in 2015, so that we can benefit from an extended period of operating leverage. 
We emerge from 2014 in an excellent position to take advantage of these R&D investments. We aim to show further FPGA market share gains while we expand the reach of FPGA technology, which together produce better than semi-industry growth and profitability. 
Let me now turn the call back to Scott.

---

We would now like to take questions. [Operator Instructions] Operator, would you please provide instructions and poll for questions?
