Okay. That's fine. And then in terms of last year when we were down 100 as we talked about global lifestyle of major customers and potential for $400 million to $500 million incremental revenue over the next 3 to 5 years, and I wondered if we're progressing as planned on that front.

---

【回答: Glenn Chamandy (Executives)】
Yes we are, we're growing that business, it's projected to be up about 25% next year.

---

【質問: Brian Morrison (Analysts)】
Fair enough. And then, Glenn, just last question in terms of acquisitions. You've said for a few quarters now it's a strategic priority. You've increased your credit facilities you have for the NCIB and potential acquisitions. Is it fair to say that an acquisition, it's a necessity rather than an option just to enhance your brand position just based on your relevant size?

---

【回答: Glenn Chamandy (Executives)】
No. I would not say that. I think that where we are today, we can grow significantly in every single one of the categories. I mean, we've made a huge investment over the last couple of years in building our brands and our distribution, our relationship with our customers. So there's a lot of opportunity for us for organic growth. I mean you can see this year we have a lot of organic growth in the tune of over 20 something percent 23%, 24% of just organic growth, but still the possibility is to obtain new programs that which haven't solidified yet. So our organic opportunity, and that is continuing to accelerate because as we get more placement and our stronger brand presence, we're going to continue to grow organically, because the market is so large in branded, there's a huge opportunity in house. Saying that, we did an acquisition with Doris. Although the acquisition is relatively small, it's opening up huge doors for us. It's giving us doors in the U.S. where we're going to place shear, and it's not just going in and, let's say, for example, saying I got shear, it's actually signed a full product category to our customers, which allows them to have more confidence in growing the other things that we really want to grow like our underwear and our socks and our activewear products. So the acquisitions don't have to be large in size. They have to be strategic in nature, and I think that's the key. So it's got to be something that will give us a product category, a brand strategy, a channel of distribution, a new market. I mean we're always going to be very tactical about how we approach acquisitions. We don't want to do acquisitions just for the sake of looking for top line growth, because we think we can do that with better returns by driving organic sales, and we can't just by buying companies for top line sales so everything is strategic. And I think so far if you look at every one in the acquisitions, we've done over the last 5, 6 years basically, that is sort of our MO. So we're continuing to look. We obviously have some things that we continue to look at, but nothing is embedded in our guidance today, and we're excited about our balance sheet and the ability for us to continue to look at these opportunities.

---

【質問: Stephen MacLeod (Analysts)】
My questions have all been answered.

Thank you, everyone, once again for joining us. This concludes our call today, and of course, we look forward to speaking to you very soon and we'd also like to wish you the very best for the holiday season. Have a great day.

2380498.eventHeadline: General Electric Company, 2014 Guidance/Update Call, Dec 16, 2014
2380498.transcript_text1:
Right, let's get started. All the forward-looking stuff, okay? We'll get right to business. A year ago, I -- we stood here, and we talked about kind of an outline for the year. It was going to be an active year, and I think we've done what we set out to do: aggressive portfolio reshaping underway; good industrial execution, including a ton of restructuring. So over the last few years, we've done more than $4 billion of restructuring to improve the cost base of the company. Simpler structure, smaller GE Capital and focus on returns. So I think as I go through this pivot in 2015 and '16, what you're going to see is the world's best infrastructure company where every business in the company leverages the core competency and very tightly, the core capability of the company; $40 billion returned to investors over the next few years in dividends and the Synchrony split, so kind of what we outlined last year is underway; substantial EPS tailwind with restructuring Alstom, buyback, not having restructuring exceed gains, industrial execution. Smaller GE Capital, we continue to make it smaller and cultural simplification and accountability, and I'll talk about all those things today. And the output of that is going to be a good, solid, double-digit EPS growth for the next few years. An output of it is earnings, industrial earnings exceeding 75% of our total earnings and expanding margins and returns. So I'm going to talk about all these things -- all of these things as we go through today.
Watchers of CNBC, you know there's a lot going on in the world, so that's kind of the mode we're in today. Some of them are better. I'd say the U.S. economy still feels like it's getting better. Air travel, rail travel, quite strong even today. U.S. healthcare around the edges, getting a little bit better. Some thing's the same. Most of the growth markets are the same. Natural gas prices, power demand remains the same, and certain things clearly under stress, so oil prices down, Russia tough, FX, things like that. So it's just a slow growth, full of volatility. It's kind of what we've seen since the financial crisis. Things get magnified in the short term, and that's kind of the world that we live in. But we still think there's plenty of growth out there to be had and as you pick through and go through the world.
Now oil price decline, I'm going to talk a little bit more about the Oil & Gas business in a little while, but we've been through cycles before. So we prepare all our businesses to go through a cycle, so Lorenzo and his team are working on cost out. Even before the oil prices went down, the Oil & Gas customers were really focused on improving the quality of the projects. We've been working on product standardization, things like that, for a long time. That's all going to get accelerated. And we're going to be able to pick through customers and projects that we want. I think if you're a big oil company in a time like this, GE looks better as a supplier during a time like this, so we like our competitive position. And we're going to look for opportunities, vis-à-vis share, people that we can hire, things like that.
And the rest of it kind of looks like fine. There's puts and takes, but the rest of the company looks fine. And I always find sometimes we're in the middle of one of these big macro kind of distractions and things like that. It's good to think about micro a little bit. So I've been going to China for 25 years, China's okay. The micro of China for -- in the Aviation business, the Healthcare business, a lot of -- the power business, China's fine. If you're in the commercial real estate business in China, not so good. We're not there in commercial real estate, so China's is okay.
In the resources places, if you're a low-cost producer like Saudi, you're still going forward. If you're a marginal producer like Iraq, Venezuela, it's going to be tough. It's going to be tough. I always have to remind people, the country that where still is GE most hedged to is the United States because the United States does better. Because of low gas prices, that is great for us. If low gas prices are felt broadly in Europe and U.S. and China, that's going to be good for GE.
Aviation and Transportation, the commercial spares rate, average daily order rate today is higher than any time I can ever remember. We will set record orders this year in locomotives. So when you think about the micro, it's just a little bit of a different perspective.
And then in the power market, we're working on some of our biggest power deals that we've ever had that are -- some of which will be announced yet this year on power projects. So people need electricity. They're going to still invest in power projects.
So the micro is still okay. There's going to be pockets -- clearly, with oil prices down, there's going to be pockets of that get filled in. But I think looking at the micro sometimes is helpful as you go through things like this.
Our framework on the year, we're still on track for the Industrial double-digit segment growth for the year and margin expansion, organic growth and margin expansion. My sense, we said revenues in the quarter would be above the high end of the range. That still looks like what we're tracking to. And revenue for the year will be close to the high end of the range, organic growth. That's what's still what we're tracking to in 2014.
Capital's tracking more to a $6.9 billion number than a $6.7 billion number. We're going to do more restructuring and charges in the quarter, a couple of pennies more. Again, we've done a ton of restructuring this year, guys, without gains. So going forward, we're going to go back to gains offsetting restructuring, but this year, to get ready for the Synchrony spin, get our industrial costs down, we've been very aggressive with restructuring this year.
CFOA is tracking towards the middle of that range on CFOA. And revenues, I already went through in terms of how we're tracking for organic growth for the year. So that's kind of the framework as we look at it this year.
And now I'm going to switch to kind of a strategic update, and then, at the end, I'll go through segment by segment and give you how we're looking at 2015. So look, we're tracking to have the world's best infrastructure company. By '16, more than 75% of our earnings are going to be an output of that, and a smaller GE Capital. Every business in the industrial sector can leverage all of our capabilities, what we call the GE Store: technology, services, global footprint; simple structure. Every business is going to be able to fully leverage that and take advantage of it. A good, solid industrial EPS growth through the period and a smaller Financial Services and one that's based really on competitive advantage and returns when we think about the total portfolio.
We've done a lot of work over the last 10 years on the portfolio. I would say a couple of things industrially. We're just more diversified industrially within each business, and we've exited all the industrial businesses that didn't fit the infrastructure model. So we've exited Appliances, plastics, silicones, business like that.
When I stood here, let's say, in 2002, more than 50% of our earnings came from 1 product and 1 market. F turbines in the United States was 50% of the company's industrial earnings. So we have very actively, within Healthcare, within power, within Aviation broadened our capability. And so I like standing here today with the set of infrastructure businesses that all utilize our core advantage and have more capability in their industries, more profit pools inside their industries, and that's what we have here today. 
Then on the Financial Services side, smaller. Look, we exited insurance in time. I think we got too big in consumer finance, and we had to go backwards on that but really, focus on a smaller Financial Service business, doing things within our control. And I think Synchrony is going to turn out to be a good trade for investors as we go through this.
So focus on staying close to domain, doing deals of the right size, really generating strong returns in the synergies. These are the things as I look forward in the company going forward. And I think where we stand here today, just less portfolio activity and very tight focus on returns, very tight focus on returns as we stand here today thinking about the portfolio and where we stand.
We did 3 big deals in 2014: Alstom, which I'll talk a little bit more about, in a sector we know very well, complementary, financially attractive, generating synergies, high-double digit returns, high-teens returns. 
Synchrony, that we've done, the first part of Synchrony. We've asked for you to model Synchrony as if we'll have it for the full year in 2015, but we're going to look to execute on the remainder of Synchrony as soon as we can in the year, but that's just for modeling purposes, the way I think about it. Look, based on current pricing and things like that, this is going to be attractive, maybe as much as 700 million shares, plus or minus, that we're going to be able to exchange and a big gain in Synchrony. 
And then Appliances, we think we did a fair trade, another gain in the Appliance business, attractive buyer. So these are 3 big deals that we did this year that we think executed on the strategy in an important way.
So with Synchrony, what does capital look like? I'd say, by the end of 2015 x Synchrony, we'll be below $300 billion of ENI. We'll continue to exit Australia, central and European banks, things like that. We're focused on the verticals or places where we have a competitive advantage. We're going to be building regulatory capability and look to enter the CCAR process in 2017 and focus on improving returns.
And then I always hate to give kind of single-point guidance, but I find with GE Capital, it's helpful for investors just to know how we're thinking about it. I would think about $0.60 a share in 2015, and with Synchrony out and fewer gains and things like that, about $0.40 a share in '16. We're still thinking about ways in an investor-friendly way to continue to reduce the size of GE Capital, driving a consistent dividend and improving returns in terms of the business and where it is.
In terms of Alstom, we're in the midst of the integration process. There's -- we've got more than 300 people working on this full time. There's things we know and can talk about. There's things we -- they're still a public company, so I'm limited in terms of how much I can really say. But the synergy pipeline's robust. They've got good people. They've got good factories. They've got good people. Its products and technologies we know. It dramatically expands the global operations of the company in an important way. What is -- as expected, the technology is kind of what we knew it was; where it fits. In some places, it's much better than what we have, particularly in areas of grid, but very complementary.
The people, we've known. When we did the EGT acquisition in the late '90s, these were all Alstom folks, so we know them quite well.  The government processes and compliance monitors are on track within our deal case, so that's important. We've hired some ex-Bechtel people to go through the EPC process with us to learn a lot about the project, so we're going through that. So far, it looks like a pretty good capability. And the first half cash was lower than they expected and due to tough markets, but it's going to improve in the second half, and we already see a pathway on that.
So that's kind of the update. We're -- for the planning purposes, we're counting on a mid-2015 close. Let's say, midyear, so that seems to be a pretty decent assumption vis-à-vis where we are today.
This goes back to last April when we laid out the synergy plan. We talked about $400 million of synergies and supply chain and services, and that looks pretty good. There's a 10-point margin delta between our service business and their service business, so that looks like a pretty good place to hunt. 1,000 combined sites, 1/3 of which are in the same city; that looks like a decent place to hunt. And like I said, the manufacturing processes are quite good. We're quite impressed with their manufacturing team, and we like what they're doing.
There's a ton of juice in sourcing. There's like $1 billion -- more than $1 billion that either 1 of us buy that the other company makes, right. So if you slap on a 20% margin on that, you wake up in the morning with just $200 million just by replacing suppliers, and that looks pretty good, $12 billion combined buy. Technology, very complementary skills.
If you look at our SG&A benchmarks versus theirs, there appears to be a decent amount of synergies. So the synergies look pretty good. And then we didn't really count on any growth synergies, but when you look at the global footprint, when you look at the aspects of where they are and some of the things we think we can do with the installed base, there seems to be some reason to think that there might be some growth synergies.
So we've kind of laid out for you, this was -- this is going to be $0.01 accretive in 2015 all in. In '16, it's $0.06 to $0.09 accretive and then ought to grow from there. So high-teens return and improved strategic position, we like the way Alstom is lining out so far. A ton of potential, just a ton of potential, but it's going to take our best effort, and we're going to have to dedicate a lot of people, a lot of management time to it to be successful in this field.
And then you look at just what the combined entity looks like. From an infrastructure standpoint, this is a fine company. This is a fine set of businesses. We ought to have a couple of years of -- with the Alstom synergies and the buyback and just organic -- reasonable organic growth and gains and restructuring offsetting. You're going to get a couple of strong years as far as we can see with -- in the environment we see today of good earnings growth. You've got a strong set of #1 franchises that are in this business, all of which can leverage the GE core. It makes the company's core capabilities even stronger, so it makes us a better technology company. It strengthens our hand in growth markets. It gives us probably more than a $200 billion service backlog. We think there's opportunity for incremental returns here. Just getting the Alstom synergies is quite strong, but it also is going to play into the work we're doing on ROIC and gross margins and more scale on a simpler foundation. And we're going to be in the middle of global infrastructure, energy transitions, growth markets, efficiency, environmental investing, a whole series of things. So you're going to have a great-looking industrial company going forward really built on our GE capability.
And the GE capability looks something like this. We talk about this a lot of different ways a lot of different times, but in some way, shape or form, we've talked about the same 4 initiatives for the last decade or so. This is a great technology company that spreads ideas throughout the company with a global research center, a legitimate global research center that spreads ideas. This is a fantastic global company that's got a global growth organization led by a Vice Chairman who sits in Hong Kong, where we have a very strong franchise in all these countries around the world. It's fantastic with services and customers, with a software COE, a service counsel and some of the best service operations in the world. And it's a -- this Lean culture heading towards 12% SG&A as a percentage of revenue with cultural development, training and development and things like that. And every one of our industrial businesses now can trade fully on this capability.
At the same time, every one of the businesses adds to this capability. So in the case of aircraft engines, aircraft engines is a first mover on engineering productivity material science. Aviation is the business that delivered CMCs, which power business now uses, and additive manufacturing that the Healthcare business now uses.
Healthcare is the anchor tenant in every growth market around the world. We had 2,000 employees in Healthcare in the year 1999. All of the original staffing for the power business, the Aviation business came from Healthcare. Most of the diagnostics technology we use across the service installed base comes from Healthcare.
Transportation business brings combustion science, engine technology, localization, again, a first mover in lot of the countries around the world.
The power business really brings the services installed base and the services capability. The power business has 17 facilities that every business, Transportation, Oil & Gas, uses. Oil & Gas has been the first mover in Africa and lots of other hard places to get to, brings a ton in service technology, great applications and controls. Energy Management, all of the power conversion, electrification controls technology comes from Energy Management back into the GE Store. So I think as you think about this, what makes GE work? It's this very strong core competency and a very great capability built around these core aspects in terms of who we are and what we do, and that's the GE Store.
Now we're going to make the GE Store better. So a lot about what we've been executing on in the past and a lot about what we're going to be doing in the future is built really on this page. And then I'm going to amplify it in the future -- in the next couple of pages.
Technology today isn't just about delivering new features. You also have to deliver it at a fundamentally lower cost point. We're doing technologies and manufacturing at the same time. When we invest in R&D, we're investing as much in manufacturing as we have any time in our history, absolutely key, absolutely key. We are going to be a huge player in globalization and in growth markets. We're going to have the world's biggest franchise with a ton of localization capability.
Three, we really do believe that every industrial company, everybody in your universe is going to have to be basic and analytics and information technology. We fundamentally believe that. And we're putting our money where our mouth is, and we're going to continue to do that, and we think we're going to win doing that.
Four, based on all of those things, I think we have underwritten the healthiest service franchise in the world. Your highest margin as an investor, your most valuable asset is the installed base, we've made that even more valuable, and I'll show you the ways we're going to do that in the future.
Five, we're going to take simplification that we've talked about on our structural cost, and we are in the midst of driving that massively into gross margins and ROIC. So we've got a lot of juice there, and we're going to continue to be -- use that to be able to drive our margins.
And six, just the strong culture of simplification and accountability are critical in terms of how we look at the future driving FastWorks and the other parts of the company. So this is really executing our strategy.
We've got great products. Our products differentially are the best that I can remember. On a differential basis, we've got a great position. H turbine, highest efficient, largest gas turbine in the world. It's a bigger part of the segment. We've got 37 technical wins. We are going to really do a great job with the H turbine.
Tier 4 locomotive, we're nearly the only one approved to get a lot of orders, and that's how I started my career, with selling Lexan. We were the only polycarbonate company in the world. We thought we were geniuses as salespeople. When you have the only one, it's a good thing, right.
LEAP engine, our win rate is huge right now on the LEAP. We're doing quite well in terms of how we're positioned. This is going to be a huge launch on the LEAP engine.
PET/MR, I was at the RSNA, and we had the best alignment of new products I can remember in a long time. We were behind Siemens on the PET/MR. It's much better. Our MR product line, CT product line, ultrasound, we just we look really good in the healthcare sector right now.
Lots of Oil & Gas innovation. 20k BOP is going to get launched. It's highly efficient and highly effective. And Power Conversion is a very important horizontal capability in terms of the company and is going to see some good growth for GE going forward. So we really have a great array of products right at the right time, ready to launch.
But we're also making them in a different way. When we increased our R&D as a percentage of revenue from 4% to 5%, that extra piece, a lot of it went into manufacturing technology. And that's going to pay off for our investors as we do that in a number of important ways.
Materials and additives, you've heard us talk about -- you've heard Dave Joyce talk about CMCs but also this strong manufacturing capability that we bring across the product line.
Design and test, this is unsexy as hell, but we have a test stand in Greenville that can do full-load gas turbine testing. It is awesome. You can now take the product. We can iterate the product. We can bring customers to see the product. People will insure the product. Insurance companies will insure the product. Testing is a massive advantage and something that we have a leadership position in.
I would say the choice to do vertical integration, with the way we design our products now, we basically own all the designs. We can choose how much we want to chew off on vertical integration, but we're going to get more margin. We're either going to get it through lower sourcing pricing or by doing more ourselves. 
And just digitalization, we're taking all of the things we talked about in Minds & Machines, and we're applying that back into our own factories.
So if you if you look at the LEAP, the LEAP has got a lower starting point and a faster learning curve than the GEnx. It's been designed more efficiently than the GEnx and is going to have a lower fundamental cost. And as you guys know, as Dave would tell you with the LEAP, 1 or 2 points either way is worth hundreds of millions of dollars over the lifetime of the product.
And the H turbine is going to start with a lower initial cost and with a faster learning curve, more productivity than any of the products we've ever introduced. So we really have aligned cost and technology very well in this process.
We're going to be a $60 billion -- GE plus Alstom is $60 billion in growth markets. We're just profoundly well positioned in just about every country that counts around the world. It's going to give us scale. It's going to give us competitive advantage. It's going to improve our scope. But when you look at a place like China, we'll have probably close to 30 factories, real critical mass across the entire company.
India, that's a place where Alstom was superior to GE, has a very strong leadership team, more factories and better position in India. Middle East, North Africa and Turkey, I talk about that, Alstom really adds to the capability and mass of the company going forward. So we now as a company are not only bigger than our competition but can really utilize and play any game strategically on a global basis, big competitive advantage.
We also have the software that goes with it. I think in the world we live in today, you just can't miss anything, right. So you're going to have to be present and get the incremental businesses that exist around the world, and you've got to do that in a cost-effective and efficient way at the same time.
So on localization, we are around the big deals as they take place. China's going to be a very active market next year in the aviation sector, lots of campaigns that we're going to have to be focused on. Most of them, they're robotic campaigns.
Like I said, emergency power, you're going to see deals yet this year that are in the emergency power space, people that need electricity. You've got to be well positioned. No 2 of these deals are the same, but when you look at a deal like Algeria, these are very important for the company strategically. We'll do about 1,000 locomotives around the world between '15 and '18. We're well positioned in a lot of places globally there.
We can compete any place in the world from a value healthcare standpoint, so can go against Mindray or others at high margins in the markets around the world. And even with oil, where it is, there's going to be some big projects in Africa next year on Subsea and Oil & Gas that GE is going to participate in and look at and work hard on. So localization helps drive growth. But by being local in these markets, we also have more presence that can improve our productivity and cost at the same time.
Now one of the things that John Rice has done as we've gone globally is really invested in these multi-modality sites. So as we invest globally, no site now is one GE business. It's multiple GE businesses. I show you here just Haiphong and Pune in India, but that's about $500 million of output, 20% savings, and we're doing this more and more on a global basis.
Engineering centers, one of the metrics that we look is operating cost per hour. So when you look at Mexico and Poland from an engineering standpoint, they have an operating cost per hour of 20% or 30% below the rest of the world. And shared services, we're doing in 5 centers now on a global basis. So globalization is giving us both a cost base and a revenue base that, again, I think, makes us very competitive in the world we live in today.
This comes from Minds & Machines. We basically discussed the investments we're making in analytics, about $300 million to $400 million a year, and this is going to add to a higher service growth rate, more dollars per installed base and higher service margins, better product feedback. It also connects us more closely to our customers. And this is still ongoing. This is still -- we're still making a ton of progress along these lines.
And we also talked about our own investment in information technology. That helps us get our 1% and helps us be more efficient with our installed base in manufacturing. And so these are things that we're going to talk about at every meeting, give you updates on and let you know how we're doing and what our capability is.
One of the important horizontal capabilities that we're investing in around the company is in controls. Controls is a critical horizontal capability for the industrial Internet. We now can take controls and back fit them in to B- and E-class turbines, the old installed base. When you do that, you open up their ability to accept the industrial Internet or accept software and analytics on top of that. We think this is going to give us a chance to drive better upgrades around the installed base.
Life optimizing controls, we're doing around all the wind turbines. This allows us to improve their uptime. This gives us ways to substantially grow the service franchise for our wind business by double digits even in a sluggish or tougher market. So controls, new technology, new ways to think about the future.
In the case of locomotives, look, our rail customers are going to allow us to be their operating ERP. This shows a real live example of a locomotive customer. We have 8 different software offerings that we're selling to this customer. It's -- the potential for each 1 of the locomotive customers is about $100 million of incremental revenue each year, dramatically increasing the dollars per installed base. The ones that don't have numbers associated with them, we're doing today, and the 1, 2, 3 are new offerings, new bids that we're driving. So this is real-time accelerating growth in our service business.
And in the case of information technology, we're aggressively driving ERP reduction, application reduction, more knowledge inside the company. And I'll just show you 2 businesses here, our Water business and our Life Science business. And as we've been able to collapse the structure of these businesses that were largely built through acquisitions, we've grown our operating profit substantially over that time period. Both of these franchises have return on capital of 15% or more. And so we're able to use the simplification of the structure and the information technology to drive better margins, lower SG&A, better returns on all these businesses going forward.
So better products, better global footprint, the intersection of physical and digital, and that investment in physical and digital leads us to really underwriting an incredibly important and valuable piece of turf for our investors, which is our installed base. We see steady growth. We're going to have another good year in '14 in services of organic growth, margins and backlog. We expect another strong year in '15. We're growing our dollars per installed base by 3%, which is very healthy. That's a good level for us. Our margins are up substantially in services this year. Our incremental software sales are strong. Our Predictivity orders will exceed $1.5 billion, and we're now looking back at this aged fleet where our penetration is lower, whether it's jet engines or locomotives or gas turbines and licking our chops about where that could go in the future. Alstom adds 35% to our installed base and there's a 10-point service differential in terms of margins there. So we see some good opportunities in our -- in -- with the acquisition.
GE brings a ton in technology. We bring a lot in terms of global footprint and Alstom actually has quite a good service business as well, particularly around the multi-vendor service and aged fleet. So we think there's a ton of complementary synergies in terms of where we stand here.
So number four is this big focus on services' profit -- long-term profit, huge backlog. Alstom's right in the sweet spot here. And this is a place where our performance is actually getting better each day, and we like where we are.
I thought I'd just take you through one business as an example, an important business, which is Power Gen Services, just to allow you to see whereas you used to have how big your installed base grew was the only determinant of whether you made more money in services year after year, you now have 5 or 6 engines that are growing simultaneously in terms of the power business. So you've always got new products. And our close rate, whether it's in aircraft engines or locomotives or Healthcare, our close rate around new technology with CSA is always huge. So you only start close to 100% on CSA close rate.
Then you add to that upgrades. You hear us talking about Advanced Gas Paths, which will be about 80, and there'll be even more next year. But on top of that, we also do upgrades to a lot of our other old fleets in terms of where we go with a ton of margin dollars associated with that.
We'll have $300 million of just software sales in the business. That's probably twice what it was in 2014. And we're going after the B and E class of fleets, so we're going after the old aged fleet with new controls and analytics. We've got a great global footprint, so our close rate globally is as high. Our close rate is as high in Australia, China, places like that, than it is in the United States, and we're generating $350 million, $400 million of productivity every year. So you march through there, and we're just changing the game around our service businesses. And I could tell the same story in Aviation or Healthcare, other businesses, so really critical.

Yes.

We'll do one more. Yes?

We still think countries like Saudi are going to be okay as you go through that. You're going to see -- again, between now and the end of the year, you're going to see big -- maybe one big order, maybe more that take place in the regions like the ones you're worried about. So there's still a big hunt for emergency power and electricity. Look, electricity matters to these places. It's the last thing to be de-invested. So I would say what we've done is underwritten our case country by country. Some of the themes that we would have had 6 months ago are gone, and some have stayed. Saudi have stayed.

---

【回答: Unknown Attendee (Attendees)】
And in terms of the holding margins in Oil & Gas, and you talk about having gotten ahead of the cost reductions now, maybe give us a little more color for what you've actually been doing there that gives us -- should give us confidence that -- we're already in, right, December. Has this already been a part of the restructuring that you've been doing? Where are you? And how should we feel comfortable that you're going to be able to match that [indiscernible]?

---

【回答: Jeffrey Immelt (Executives)】
So go back in time. So what was the thing most people would be talking about in the oil and gas industry, let's say, a year ago? It was oversold. We're sitting on 6 or 9 months of late backlog. The supply chain, if you compare the oil and gas, just -- not just GE but the whole industry. If you compare the Oil & Gas supply chain to the Aviation supply chain, it's not even close, the reliably of the suppliers, the productivity of the suppliers, the reliability of the projects, the delivery of the projects. So I would say, Steve, we've been working like mad just to clean up our own factories, suppliers, getting things on time. So we've done more than $4 billion of restructuring over the last 3 or 4 years. Some of that's been in Oil & Gas, and I would say we're going to have very aggressive base cost programs. But we also have very aggressive variable cost programs that go along with that. So it's not just the base cost set. This is a supply chain capability as well. So I think that's the way I would think about it. This was not a super-efficient industry before. There is a ton of room just to get the Oil & Gas business up to the standards of the rest of the GE -- internal GE family. Well, with that, guys, I'm just going to reiterate we -- there's things we still don't know about Oil & Gas, and we've tried to create a range that underwrites more things that we don't know. We do the best we can for where we sit here today, but we try to keep a big enough range that the downside can allow for Oil & Gas to get worse. Yes, Steve?

---

【回答: Unknown Attendee (Attendees)】
There's a lot of moving parts in Corporate with the gains and restructuring. Can you maybe just clarify? Is Alstom restructuring going to be taken in the second half of '15? Just, I guess, the puts and takes around gains and restructuring in total.

---

【回答: Jeffrey Immelt (Executives)】
So Steve, I'll do the best I can and then maybe you can hit, Jeff. I would say the gains will be in excess of $1 billion. Then those will be eaten up by -- some of it by Alstom restructuring, things associated with that and then just pure restructuring. So we'll still do pure restructuring as part of that as well, but we view kind of the closing cost, the Alstom restructuring will be in Corporate.

---

【回答: Unknown Attendee (Attendees)】
And then I thought you said for the '16 slide, you said some of that organic growth of 5% to 10%. Was that revenue growth? Or was that profit?

---

【回答: Jeffrey Immelt (Executives)】
I -- No, I didn't -- we didn't give a guidance on '16 revenue. Our long-term target is 5%, but I'm just trying to get people to think through what just happens -- we're not really thinking -- restructuring equal gains, buyback, Alstom, those 3 things are kind of -- we don't have to go out and do anything new. Those happen, and then you're going to get organic growth that happens alongside of that when you think about '16. It's too soon to...

---

【回答: Unknown Attendee (Attendees)】
And then what is your oil price assumption for, at least, this year and...

---

【回答: Jeffrey Immelt (Executives)】
We do 60 to 65. That's kind of where we are, but I -- again, like I said, I don't think we know. But that's how we did our plans in that range.

---

【回答: Unknown Attendee (Attendees)】
And then one just last one. Your free cash flow, excluding dispositions, it's about, I think, $10 billion to $11.5 billion for next year.

---

【回答: Jeffrey Immelt (Executives)】
I think it was $14 billion to $16 billion, less $4 billion to $5 billion. I said -- I think it's -- yes, so you're right, I think.

---

【回答: Unknown Attendee (Attendees)】
Yes. So you're paying out a $9 billion dividend. I assume some of that cash is overseas. I mean, are you -- how are you managing this from a liquidity perspective? Are you bringing back cash and paying the tax in an efficient way or...

---

【回答: Jeffrey Immelt (Executives)】
Well, you're going to get the chance to do Alstom out of foreign cash. You got -- we've got lots of optionality about how we think about -- we leave the year with $16 billion or more of cash. So you've got a ton of optionality around cash right now. Really, the big deals are Alstom for next year. Deane?

---

【質問: Deane Dray (Analysts)】
Jeff, interested in hearing some more thoughts on what you consider to be the optimal mix for GE because we heard a couple messages today, a big plus sign in front of that 75% and lots of arrows down on making GE Capital smaller. And Slide 9, it was pretty clear you're going to seek every opportunity to make GE Capital smaller. So what are the -- I assume you -- if you get an investor-friendly way. But what are the parameters on the GE Capital fit today? Is it risk? Is it the cash flow opportunities? You manage the SIFI requirements well, but still you want to get smaller. So just where is the optimal mix? And what are the parameters?

---

【回答: Jeffrey Immelt (Executives)】
So again, Deane, what I would say is that the output on split is more the output than the input. So when I think about the strategy of the company, it's investing in really great businesses that leverage our core capability, improve the returns, things like that, right. But when I look at GE Capital, to me, it's about competitive advantage and returns and which businesses do we have the most competitive advantage in and can we generate an attractive return for our investors, given the requirements and getting the CCAR in '17 and things like that. And then the third thing is, I just -- we have to make it under our control. I think one of the good things we've done since the financial crisis is we've only talked about things that are in our own control, like doing the Synchrony spin and things like that. So I think when you factor in all those things, it's likely going to be small. We kind of say post-Synchrony, it's going to be less than $300 billion, and I think if you look at competitive advantage, returns, doing under our control, it's likely going to be smaller than that. We're on track to be part of the CCAR process in 2017. That's meaningful. That creates optionality in that time -- maybe more in that time period. So that's how I think about it, Deane, really. We're not in it just to -- we're not in it just to be in it. We're in it to generate a good return. Jeffrey?

---

【質問: Jeffrey Sprague (Analysts)】
Just pass this mic down one at a time. I was here first. Part of the portfolio change, in a sense, at least it looks like it de-risks the portfolio as capital gets smaller, but I'm thinking kind of the flipside of that. You mentioned projects a couple of times in Oil & Gas. Obviously, with Alstom, you're moving in to balance the plant and grid work and things that have kind of been the bane of the existence of some players over the years. How do you actually manage through that? You're hiring people from Bechtel, so there's a little bit of acknowledgment that you do need some help there. And is it having any impact on your cash conversion? It looks like your cash conversion's under a little bit of pressure.

---

【回答: Jeffrey Immelt (Executives)】
So what I would say, Jeff, is the project stuff isn't something that we've actively seek-ed to increase or decrease. With the acquisition of Alstom, we have it. So we're learning about it. We're going to kind of assess our ability to run it and run it well as time goes on. We're in the integration process, so we'll learn a lot about it. But it's not -- it's neither a strategic imperative nor is it something we run away from. It just is a function of where we are. And from a cash conversion standpoint, I think any time progress and things like that go up and down as orders go up and down. But our businesses like Power & Water, Aviation, these were all 20%-plus return on capital businesses. So they still are good cash-generating, over-the-top businesses.

---

【質問: Jeffrey Sprague (Analysts)】
And just one other final thing, just on Alstom. So the -- will the restructuring actually be up in kind of the Corporate or segments? I would have thought a lot of that would have happened in purchase accounting and maybe...

---

【回答: Jeffrey Immelt (Executives)】
Yes, it's going to be there as well, Jeff. So I think a lot of it's going to be purchase accounting. But in terms of -- there's always some changes that go to -- when we've done acquisitions in the past, there's been charges that have gone to Corporate, and that's where those will be. The caveat, the corollary of that says in Power & Water, you're going to see the Power & Water segment's going to be several hundred million dollars greater. They'll have Alstom coming in, in the second half. So that's where the upside is there, yes.

---

【質問: Nigel Coe (Analysts)】
Jeff, can you just maybe talk about how 4Q orders have tracked? And I guess, specifically, have you've seen any change in behavior from customers? Either sort of the lower oil price or strong dollar, any change in behavior at all?

---

【回答: Jeffrey Immelt (Executives)】
So Nigel, I'd say -- again, guys, I'm giving you the best I see today, right. So I would say slight positive orders to be for the fourth quarter would be my hunch based on where we're tracking here today, and I think other than Oil & Gas, Aviation commercial spares, average daily order rate is the highest since -- certainly, since I've been CEO. We'll take more locomotive orders in the second half of the year than any time in our -- really, in our history. So I don't see it yet, but I'm -- China will have positive orders in the quarter, right. So I think it's always good to take pause at a time like this and be thoughtful about what's happening and things like that. So I don't want to be Nostradamus or anything like that. I just am telling you kind of what we see, and that's what we see. Clearly, Oil & Gas customers are going to do a double clutch, right, as I said, go through what they're -- some projects will go forward. Some projects won't. But on balance, we're kind of counting for -- we track what they say about CapEx and then kind of plan for things to be at least that bad, if not worse.

---

【質問: Nigel Coe (Analysts)】
And then, secondly, your friends in Bavaria have seen a very different power market in '15 than you do, price down heavily, margins down heavily. Can you just provide some perspective on the power market generally in '15, GE versus your competitors?

---

【回答: Jeffrey Immelt (Executives)】
I think the markets -- it's a competitive market, and it's a flat market. So I think that's what most of the kind of industry analysts talk about. That's kind of how we plan it. There's going to be a ton of H activity. There's going to be ton of large block activity. And then, Nigel, it just depends on where the -- there's -- a lot of the action is going to be in Japan next year. So you're going to see Japan's going to be a super big market. The U.S. is going to be a bigger market next year. So a lot of the pricing ends up being as much about the regional mix as it does about any given transaction, I think, in terms of where we go. But we're certainly not counting on the market to be superhot. Yes?

---

【回答: Unknown Attendee (Attendees)】
Just a question on oil, is low oil good for GE or bad for GE?

---

【回答: Jeffrey Immelt (Executives)】
So as you can imagine, we think a lot about that, particularly in the last months or so. I'd say, on balance, it's probably closer to watch. It's probably close to watch for a slight negative, but it's not a big negative is the way I would think about it. I'd say when our customers make more money, they spend more. But it's going to have an impact on our Oil & Gas business.

---

【回答: Unknown Attendee (Attendees)】
And just following up from Steve's question about cash flow, if you look what you're generating versus you're spending on dividends and CapEx, there's sort of not much left to play with. So do we need to wait until CCAR to get more optionality? Can you actually -- are you in a position to actually use the Industrial balance sheet beyond '16 if needed? Or is that also part of the CCAR process?

---

【回答: Jeffrey Immelt (Executives)】
Look, I still think we have debt capacity on the Industrial balance sheet. We're not counting on it. And look, if you just look at our metrics, there's more cash in GE Capital than just the pure income dividend. But we're a part of a regulatory process, and we're going to have to think about that. But, guys, look, we've got a fantastic set of Industrial businesses, and we've got all the juice we need to continue to grow the Industrial franchise. So I feel pretty good about where we are in total, but there's not a day that I don't walk past Keith and say, "How about one for the Gipper?" It's -- okay - just. Hey, Joe?

---

【質問: Joseph Ritchie (Analysts)】
Jeff, so your Industrial gross margins the last few years have been on a bit of a decline, and some of that is due to we've had this massive equipment cycle. But look, you look at your service, backlog is up strongly. Some of your simplification efforts are coming through. You're starting to incentivize gross margin expansion. At what point do you start to see gross margins turn up?

---

【回答: Jeffrey Immelt (Executives)】
I think we've already told you that we expect to see them up next year.

---

【質問: Joseph Ritchie (Analysts)】
And is there a specific target then beyond next year?

---

【回答: Jeffrey Immelt (Executives)】
50 basis points. I think we've said 50 a year for the next couple of years. We've kind of targeted everything through '16, so we're kind of saying 50 a year in '15 and '16. And so what we've done is we've underwritten that, I think, including as much mix as we can see. Mix has certainly hurt us, but it's not a good excuse. I think we can do a better job on gross margins.

---

【質問: Joseph Ritchie (Analysts)】
And the follow-up is on the $135 billion in noncore assets that you're looking at potentially aggressively divesting. Can you talk a little bit about the timing? How are you thinking about potentially the use of those proceeds once you eventually divest of those assets?

---

【回答: Jeffrey Immelt (Executives)】
Look, I think the -- so we've talked a little bit about Australia consumer. You've seen the announcements on the Hungarian bank. We're going to keep aggressively going after all that consumer red assets, make those smaller. As we shrink, there ought to be more cash optionality in GE Capital. So we would expect that to be reflected over time in terms of how we go. And Synchrony should be a couple of billion dollar gain. It depends on where the stock is and where it closes and when we do it, and that will give us more optionality to continue to reduce red assets faster. Yes, let me go here. Yes, Julian?

---

【質問: Julian Mitchell (Analysts)】
Just a question on Healthcare because you could -- from the outside, you could look at it and say, "All it is, is sort of relentless cost-cutting." And also you had that slide 7 on...

---

【回答: Jeffrey Immelt (Executives)】
Different from every other business, huh?

---

【質問: Julian Mitchell (Analysts)】
Right. Well, you had Slide 7 on improving the portfolio that had this sort of equals sign against Healthcare. I wasn't really sure what that meant. You had a leadership change recently at the business. So just...

---

【回答: Jeffrey Immelt (Executives)】
I think on the portfolio moves. So look, my view is that Amersham's going to generate its cost of capital. I'm glad we did it. Healthcare IT, we acquired IDX. We should have been at better position for the EMR wave. That's a pivot we should have done a better job at. These businesses pivot. These businesses -- think about the Power business, right. We went through the gas turbine bubble, but we've led in wind. We've led in distributed power. We've made every good pivot that the business has to make to be successful. So as these businesses, as Oil & Gas goes through a cycle, as Aviation goes through a cycle, as Power & Water has gone through maybe the biggest of all cycles, the team pivoted extremely well. And look, we were on the field with a pretty good franchise in Healthcare IT and just didn't execute as well as -- and that was the wave of growth, Julian, over the last 5 years. Now we're going to be able to catch the next wave, but that's what you should expect us to do. In terms of health care, look, the market has been -- we've gone through a massive consolidation. Customers have kind of sat on their wallet for a couple of years. Procedures have started to grow again. If you go back over time, procedure growth has always been a precursor for new capital equipment growth. My expectation is that the U.S. has a decent year. Europe is going to be very tough. China, instead of growing double digits, will probably grow high-single digits in health care. But I think all we're asking John to do is kind of low- to mid-single digit revenue growth, expand margins and be ready, be positioned.

---

【質問: Julian Mitchell (Analysts)】
And then just on Industrial overall, you used to give some color on the margin, sort of puts and takes, value gaps, simplification, R&D. How does that look for next year putting Alstom aside?

---

【回答: Jeffrey Immelt (Executives)】
So we've got another big year on -- we've got -- so we're expecting margin growth next year. So we expect to be 13%, let's say more or less; SG&A percentage of revenue next year. So we expect the SG&A to continue to come down, and we expect gross margins to be better. And that SG&A, Julian, will be a mixture of different stuff, but that's kind of the pathway we've shown you guys, and we expect to be on that pathway. Hey, John?

---

【回答: Unknown Attendee (Attendees)】
So the past few years have been characterized by industrial companies focusing their operations, either through tax-free spins or whatnot, and one of the thematics of your pitch very much was big companies like GE have competitive advantages to play in these global arenas. None of us would have expected that deal the size of Alstom as you had been bolt-on centric, I realize that's key theme to you. So how are you now, just as a starting point, thinking about big acquisitions, both in that context and then being opportunistic, considering you've done the biggest deal ever?

---

【回答: Jeffrey Immelt (Executives)】
Look, I just -- I like the way the company looks right now. I think, John, we basically have exited businesses that didn't use the GE Store. Appliances, we weren't in it to win, didn't use our core capability. Every business we have uses [indiscernible] to win. So [indiscernible] there. I like the company the way it looks today. The second thing I'd say is Alstom has a tremendous value-creating potential for our investors, but it's going to take all of our hard work to do it. We have plenty on our plate for next year to execute on, on Alstom, and I'm just -- we're just not that interested in doing another. Given we like what we have and we've got good value-creating work on our plate right now, that's enough for right now.

---

【回答: Unknown Attendee (Attendees)】
Yes. No, in fact, I think you said that's M&A for '15, '16, right?

---

【回答: Jeffrey Immelt (Executives)】
Yes.

---

【回答: Unknown Attendee (Attendees)】
So okay, here's my sort of, kind of the corollary question. This whole supply-driven dynamics we're in with respect to oil, I guess a lot of us believe that this starts in '15 but spills -- unless there's some sort of shift, this is going to spill into '16. So you guys have made a big energy footprint commitment for presumably forever. Why not retain the flexibility if market conditions provide to go after and actually get much bigger in energy in certain locations, right?

---

【回答: Jeffrey Immelt (Executives)】
Okay, John, here's the -- I think it's a great question, but let me just tell you the way I think about it, which is I think in Oil & Gas -- we like Oil & Gas. I'll go back. We like Oil & Gas. We're diversified in Oil & Gas. We think this is a seminal business for the world. And we want to be in it, and we are in it. In this kind of volatility, GE is a very good person for any NOC or IOC to do business with, right. If you're an IOC and you want to test $65 a barrel on your new projects, you're going to come to GE to do that. So why would I pay anybody goodwill right now when basically our competitive position is better today, relatively speaking, than it was a month ago? I think that's the bottom line right now. There's just no reason to have to do that. Our relative competitive position in the businesses we're in has gotten better. These are cycles we know. We have fundamental strength that other people don't have. Look, we can all arm-wrestle over the value of a conglomerate, right. We can all arm-wrestle that one. This exactly the right time to want to be in a multi-business company, exactly the right time. Because our company is going to grow double-digit EPS next year even with a much worse oil case than the one we see today. Because Aviation is doing great, and Transportation is doing great, and we've got Alstom, and we've got a bunch of other stuff under way. Those are things that FMC doesn't have. Those are things that Schlum [ph] doesn't have. Those are things that none of these guys have. I like us in that field right now. Chris?

---

【回答: Unknown Attendee (Attendees)】
Jeff, a lot of talk about gross margin today. Haven't really noticed it being part of your messaging in the past so much. So I'm just wondering what caused that to precipitate at such a big line today. And just if you could comment on observation that if you combine that with your SG&A targets, it would seem to put you through the 17% margin target.

---

【回答: Jeffrey Immelt (Executives)】
So look, I'd say we have had a tremendous amount of mix headwind, Chris. And I think before we talk publicly to you guys about stuff, it's typically stuff we've been working on for a year or 2. So we've kind of been percolating, I would say, the programs around gross margins, and it's the way you get to 17%. You got to have both things working, and we've got to allow a little bit of room for mix. It's just -- I think that's probably something we can do a better job of. So a, it's taken a while, we've got the programs in place; b, I always thought SG&A was a tremendous place to start just because the nature of the company had changed so vastly, right. Just the global footprint of GE is so different today than it was when I became CEO. Our cost was in the wrong place. Our processes were in the wrong place. So the simplification around SG&A was the best place to focus and, again, I think the combination of Dan and Jeff and Jamie and other people, we've got a good set of leaders to get it done.

---

【回答: Unknown Attendee (Attendees)】
Okay. So the 50 basis [indiscernible] is independent of it?

---

【回答: Jeffrey Immelt (Executives)】
Yes. So in other words, that includes mix, right.  Yes, yes. One or -- a couple more. Yes, how are you doing? Good.

---

【回答: Unknown Attendee (Attendees)】
Just building on some of the previous questions, if we think about just your embedded assumptions for '15 and '16, either quantitative or qualitatively around price across the board.

---

【回答: Jeffrey Immelt (Executives)】
On pricing of back -- on like pure price?

---

【回答: Unknown Attendee (Attendees)】
Yes. So I think you have a 2% to 5% organic growth target for '15. But obviously, you've been talking about a lot of initiatives around gross margin and then, obviously, you have a deflationary environment for oil, which will also put some...

---

【回答: Jeffrey Immelt (Executives)】
So here's what I would say. I would say we had a positive value gap this year. Our expectation is that we have a positive value gap in '15, and I just think it's too soon to forecast around '16, right? So I think you've got a lot of positive momentum, a lot of things already in the backlog, and there's just nothing deflation -- or there's nothing inflationary in my world today fundamentally. So we're going to pricing pressure in Oil & Gas. We're going to have price -- maybe gas turbines pricing pressure, stuff like that. But there's nothing we really look at as incoming that's inflationary at all. So we would expect, in fact, to get incremental deflation with oil price as well.

---

【回答: Unknown Attendee (Attendees)】
So negative prices for '15 -- early '15?

---

【回答: Jeffrey Immelt (Executives)】
Again, I think we look at a positive value gap, which would probably mean orders pricing will be flat to up slightly, and we'll get deflation, right. So you'll have a positive value gap. But how that plays out in '16, it's just too soon to think about it.

---

【回答: Unknown Attendee (Attendees)】
And just the last question in some -- just around the change in some of the incentives, both at the, I guess, segments and at the C-suite. Could you just comment, what do you think you've changed for the better? Or what have you tried to do to try to modernize it?

---

【回答: Jeffrey Immelt (Executives)】
Again, I think we always, as managers, maximize -- always want to maximize judgment in terms of how you -- so we've always done goals and objectives for the company. We flow those all the way down. They've always been numerically based forever, for 30 years I've been with GE. I think the change we've made is just much more formulaic. Really, it puts judgment aside and basically says, "What do you want to see as an investor?" And now you have 5,000 people that are going to get paid that way. So it's just complete pass-through from what you want in the company to what a executive band plant manager in Aviation, how they see their incentive comp, and it's always been directionally the same. Now it is linear, and I think that's -- in an uncertain world, that's certain. That's better. Maybe, Matt, you want to do one more?

---

【回答: Matthew Cribbins (Executives)】
Yes.

---

【回答: Jeffrey Immelt (Executives)】
We'll do one more. Yes?

---

【回答: Unknown Attendee (Attendees)】
Just sort of 2 questions quickly. One is just going back to the lack of likelihood of doing M&A in the oil and gas space. Is part of that related to the obvious that Alstom cost you 2 to 3x more than you had expected to spend on acquisitions a couple of years ago? Is that part of it, that you feel like you...

---

【回答: Jeffrey Immelt (Executives)】
It's just -- I come back, guys, and say -- look, I mean, I don't think -- we've got every box covered that we want basically in the space and, fundamentally, I think our competitive position is better today than it was 6 months ago. So organically, we can generate a ton of value versus buying anything. So I never want to say never. I just don't view it as a strategic imperative for the company.

---

【回答: Unknown Attendee (Attendees)】
Okay. And just secondly, can you talk a little bit about how you're looking out over the next years, how you're thinking about buyback versus dividend? And I know you've joked around offline of you won't retire until you get the dividend back up to the higher watermark. Can you talk to us a little bit about that?

---

【回答: Jeffrey Immelt (Executives)】
Look, the buyback -- I think Synchrony was a tremendous way to, in a capital-efficient way, buy back a ton of shares at the same time. And so look, we talked about that more than a year ago. It's now coming more into focus, so that's a very capital-efficient way to do it. I think the company's well positioned organically. We still invest a lot in organic growth. So we think that's important, and people like -- a vast majority of our investors still like seeing the dividend grow in line with earnings. So I would say dividend in line with earnings. Let's do a great job of integration on Alstom and then see where we are in M&A, and let's do -- use incremental capital beyond that for buybacks. But Synchrony, right now, is the key driver for the buyback, and that's -- between dividend and buyback, $40 billion over 2 years is pretty good, pretty good.
So let me end there. The team, the team is all here. So cocktails, you can -- Lorenzo, I'm sure, will be a popular guy at cocktail. So I'll let Lorenzo on his own. And thanks, and we'll see you -- we'll circulate. Great.

2447218.eventHeadline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2014
2447218.transcript_text1:
Thank you, Elise. Hello, everyone, and welcome to Red Hat's earnings call for the third quarter of our fiscal 2015. Speakers on today's call will be: Jim Whitehurst, President and CEO; and Charlie Peters, Executive Vice President and CFO.

Again, it's hard for me to give a lot of color on that, because just as a reminder, when a customer buys a subscription, they buy a subscription to RHEL. They can decide to use 5, 6 or 7. And so it doesn't have an impact on our economics. And therefore, frankly, we don't track that super closely. Obviously, more advanced features hopefully will lead to more sales. But for our traditional customers, that doesn't affect us, on whether they're running 6 or 7. So we should start seeing a real move in production with the 0.1, and that's kind of normal. We don't expect to see that on the 0.0.

---

【回答: Tom McCallum (Executives)】
Great. Next question please.

---

【質問: S. Kirk Materne (Analysts)】
Just really quickly, Jim, can you talk -- or Charlie, could you talk to us about the emerging product adoption, I guess x-JBoss, just from a geographic perspective? I assume the U.S. is sort of leading the charge on that front, and I guess if that's true, could you just talk about what needs to happen, in terms of seeing some uptake in Europe or Asia over the next year, to sort of compliment what you're seeing in the U.S., if that indeed is the way it's going right now?

---

【回答: Charles Peters (Executives)】
I think I have the grift of your question. First of all, we don't break down emerging products any finer than that, but I would say this: I think it's a fair assumption that a lot of our largest accounts and reference accounts, they generally start with new products closer to home. And then, as they are comfortable and we are comfortable in it, it begins to populate into Europe, Latin America, Asia and so forth. So since Middleware has been around longer than some of the other technologies in that group, it's probably a safe assumption that it is spread more globally than some of the newer technologies. But I can tell you that every region in the world is looking to sell each of the technologies in emerging products growth. And so we think all the regions are going to have good prospects for those products.

---

【回答: Tom McCallum (Executives)】
Operator, we have time for one more question, please.

---

【質問: Edward Maguire (Analysts)】
I just was wondering if you could comment on the competitive environment around your core Linux business. How much is really driving this big deal momentum in the core business? Is it -- are you seeing -- continuing to see standardization? Are their Windows displacements? Is there -- how much UNIX displacement is still left to be done?

---

【回答: James Whitehurst (Executives)】
Yes. And I'll start with that. I mean, displacement, there's some. But we primarily take share by winning new workloads. And I think what's we're seeing is a very substantial move towards net new workloads going on Linux, relative to Windows. And so we -- the IDC shows that we're taking market share. I think we believe taking market shares, we're winning those that new workloads. We can -- we still do a lot of UNIX to Linux, a lot of our large customers, as they get deeper with us, continue to move more workloads over. So we still see that as a movement and that will continue going forward. There are some replatformings from Windows to Linux, but it's much more customers saying, my next generation of applications is going to go on Linux, and especially when you start moving to scale-out cloud type infrastructures, whether that's OpenStack or something else. Those are heavily, heavily Linux based. And obviously, our customers want to have their scale-up applications are already on RHEL. And so they want to stay on that standard environment, so that just kind of keeps those growing for us.

---

【回答: Tom McCallum (Executives)】
Great. Thanks, Jim. Thanks, operator. This concludes our third quarter earnings call. We look forward to speaking to everyone the rest of this year and into next year. And happy holidays, everyone.
