Do you have any sense of how your PCLs might look a year from today if oil is still at $65 or in and around the range? PCLs from Canada I mean, specifically.

【回答: Mark Hughes (Executives)】
Yes. At this point, they would still be within the range of our normal expectations.

---

【回答: David McKay (Executives)】
Right.

---

【質問: Peter Routledge (Analysts)】
This is a slow issue?

【回答: Mark Hughes (Executives)】
Yes.

So if you're at a comfortable level, will you start -- restart, I should say, your NCIB this quarter or next quarter?

【回答: Janice Fukakusa (Executives)】
We're -- Peter, it's Janice. We're always looking at the levels and opportunities to do that, and we did renew the NCIB because it's our intention to use it as an active capital management tool.

---

【質問: Sohrab Movahedi (Analysts)】
Janice, just maybe a bit of a difficult question to answer. But if you think about the overall tech spend budget, looking into 2015, how much higher do you think it's going to have to be versus 2014?

---

【回答: Janice Fukakusa (Executives)】
Because of the way that we do technology projects in that we have multiyear projects and we're always reinvesting, I would say that our tech spend budget will be very consistent next year to what we have just gone through this year. Because the nature of our programs and our commitment to invest in new technology in terms of simplifying our processes for our clients, innovation, all of that, we don't see any major shift in that. We started with these programs, a lot of them, 2 or 3 years ago, and some of them are midstream. ---

【質問: Sohrab Movahedi (Analysts)】
Okay. And do you see any shift in the mix of that spend between the business segments?

---

【回答: Janice Fukakusa (Executives)】
No, we -- I don't see any shift at all in the mix.

---

【質問: Steve Theriault (Analysts)】
First, for Doug McGregor, the decline in fixed income trading -- I apologize if this is a repeat question, by the way. But the decline in fixed income trading looks to be more than slower client activity, to me, at any rate. So I guess what I'm wondering is were there material mark-to-market losses in the fixed income books through that mid-quarter or that mid-October period of high volatility with spreads widening. Or would you really insist that it was more client activity levels?

---

【回答: A. McGregor (Executives)】
Well, if you look at the FIC numbers, the headline items, first of all is the FVA. Second, that I described earlier, is that we had a credit opportunity strategy in our proprietary business that we determined to take off, and I think it was a result of -- just marks as a result of illiquidity in early and mid-October. I would say, overall, the rest of the weakness was rates was gapping up and down for the better part of 30 days. And we had, I think if you look in the disclosure, 10 or 11 days of trading losses, and they would have been $5 to $10, but that was a mix of in-GAAP in Europe -- or sorry, in FIC in Europe and the U.S. And I would say our credit books in the U.S. also were just -- we were just marking inventory and trying to provide liquidity to our clients and our customers and it got expensive. So I think as the numbers come out, you will see a trend that it was a difficult trading environment in fixed income.

---

【質問: Steve Theriault (Analysts)】
Okay. The credit opportunity strategy you took off, is that Volcker related? Or that was taken off for some other reason?

---

【回答: A. McGregor (Executives)】
Yes, yes. It was part of the proprietary business that, as we said, we've had for a long time, and we didn't see that, anyway, that was going to comply with Volcker longer term. So the strategies that we determined would not comply, we have wound down, and the people have left.

---

【質問: Steve Theriault (Analysts)】
Okay, that's helpful. And Janice, just to -- just a point of clarification. Earlier on the call, did you talk about efficiency ratio in Canadian Banking being below 40%, I thought I caught that, relative to the -- what I thought the low 40% target rate?

---

【回答: Janice Fukakusa (Executives)】
No. Steve, it was low 40s, consistent with what we've been targeting.

---

A question in relation to the Wealth Management segment and the restructuring as well as the outlook going forward. So if I got your comments correct at the beginning, Dave, I think you said the businesses that you're disposing of are about 5% of revenue, but it sounds like not a very big contribution to earnings. Is that correct?

---

【回答: David McKay (Executives)】
I'll let George maybe comment on that. But yes, that's correct, it's not material.

---

【質問: Sumit Malhotra (Analysts)】
Well -- and before George, I'll just ask. As you think about the wealth segment going forward, are there other areas of the business, particularly outside of Canada, that are under review in terms of the potential restructuring -- or potential attempts of restructuring those as well going forward?

---

【回答: M. Lewis (Executives)】
So Sumit, I'll take that. And the -- as Dave commented in his remarks, these restructuring activities in our international wealth business, it does represent a very small component of our wealth segment. And this will not impact our Global Asset Management business, which, to your point, has a very large footprint outside of Canada. It's growing well, positive flows. And it won't affect our Canadian and U.S. wealth domestic businesses either. So stepping back, for context, these international businesses at one point in time, in 2008, 2009, represented about 20% of our segment earnings. They're now close to breakeven as we've invested in strengthening the infrastructure front and middle office during a period of -- extended period of low interest rates. So what we've done is take a look at this, which has negatively impacted our trust and deposit revenues, and decided to narrow our country and client focus and concentrate on serving those international cross-border clients from our key international center in our channels where we do have scale. So that will take some time to implement. We're looking at all strategic options for the various components of the international wealth business, including identifying interested parties to purchase portions of those operations. But this will not impact our large high-performing businesses in Global Asset Management or Canadian wealth or U.S. wealth, which really drove an excellent year for us this year in terms of earnings up 22%.

---

【質問: Sumit Malhotra (Analysts)】
So George, to wrap it up, I know we've had this discussion a few times over the years. But when you think about the pretax margin in the segment this year just under 24% and specifically against some of the targets that you'd provided in the past that you wanted the segment to get to and taking this first step to reposition the business, where do you think margins of this business improve to? I can probably do some of the math myself, but wanted to get your outlook on what's a more reasonable goal now that you've taken this step on the wealth side.

---

【回答: M. Lewis (Executives)】
Yes, sure. So I think we anticipate continuing to make progress in improving our pretax margin. Our Global Asset Management business, which represents about 60% of our earnings, is a very high-margin business, 50% pretax margins. It's why we are intent on continuing to grow it. Obviously, as we exit lower-margin businesses in international wealth, that's going to naturally improve our pretax margin, which remains our principal goal. I'd also say that looking forward to next year, we're conscious that we've benefited from robust markets in both 2013 and 2014. Our earnings were up 18% last year, 22% this year. And our plan is based on normal markets, and we intend to aim to deliver positive operating leverage in a lower revenue growth environment in 2015, if that comes to pass.

---

【回答: David McKay (Executives)】

We understand where the growth is going to come from, and I think it's good discipline for the business to really focus on where -- focus on where that growth's going to come from. So these are important moves for us to manage areas that don't have scale and we don't believe have long-term potential for us.

---

【回答: David McKay (Executives)】
I just wanted to thank everyone for joining us on the call today. And I do wish you happy holidays, and we will see you again in the new year. Thanks very much, everybody.

2804211.eventHeadline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, 2014 Guidance/Update Call, Dec 12, 2014
2804211.transcript_text1:
Thanks, Jesse. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. 
Today, we're pleased to have the opportunity to discuss the major new customer initiative for Sherwin-Williams. On Wednesday evening, after the market close, Lowe's Improvement Centers and Sherwin-Williams issued a joint press release announcing that our HGTV HOME by Sherwin-Williams branded paints will be available Lowe's stores throughout the United States and on Lowe's.com, beginning the spring of 2015.  Yesterday, Lowe's senior management shared some detail and answered the questions about this new paint offering at their Investor Conference Day. One purpose of our call today is to add our comments, as well as answer any questions you might have about Sherwin-Williams' role in this exciting program. 
The second purpose of our call is to update our guidance for 2014 and provide preliminary expectations for 2015 full year sales and diluted net income per common share. 
To begin with, I'd like to turn the call over to John Morikis to walk you through some of the highlights of the Lowe's program, and then I'll back to summarize our expectations for 2014 and 2015. John?

---

Thanks, Chris. Let me begin by saying how excited we are about this opportunity to expand our relationship with Lowe's. They are a long-standing valued customer of our company, and we have great respect for them as a retailer. 
We believe the HGTV HOME by Sherwin-Williams brand, product line and color features are a perfect fit for their paint department. As most of you know, the HGTV HOME by Sherwin-Williams brand was introduced in Sherwin-Williams paint stores back in 2011, and it has performed very well for us over the past 3 years. The familiarity of the HGTV brand and the user-friendly color tools appeal to younger, upscale, fashion-forward consumers, who are very involved with their home decor. 
The HGTV HOME by Sherwin-Williams product line that will be available in Lowe's stores will feature new and improved interior and exterior paint products, which will also be sold through the Sherwin-Williams company stores nationwide. 
In addition, the Lowe's program will include the some new line extensions that are exclusive to Lowe's. In total, this product lineup should appeal to the mid-tier to premium paint shopper. 
The HGTV HOME by Sherwin-Williams color palette in Lowe's will offer 16 designer-inspired color collections, 8 of which will be exclusive to Lowe's. These coordinated color cards provide a full-proof way to create a cohesive look in any one room or from room to room throughout the home, enabling homeowners to achieve the look of a professional designer. 
There'll be a total of 1,100 shades within the full color offering, including the designer-inspired collections, plus other classic colors selected by the color experts at HGTV and Sherwin-Williams. 
Additionally, Sherwin-Williams will provide Lowe's with 2 independent paint brands: Painter's Masterpiece and Property Net Advantage. These will serve professional painters and property managers. We'll begin shipping product in March. So the announcement will have very modest impact on first quarter 2015 sales. The load-in will be complete in time for Spring, the Spring painting season. We will incur some incremental merchandising and advertising expenses throughout the year to support this program. 
Again, we're excited about this new relationship with our long-time partner, Lowe's, and we have very high expectations for this program. 
Thanks again for joining us this morning, and let me turn the call back over to Chris.

---

Thanks, John. I'm sure most of you saw the press release we issued before the opening bell this morning, updating our guidance for 2014 and highlighting our expectations for 2015. We thought it was important to help you decide for some of the unusual and onetime items impacting our results in the fourth quarter and into 2015. We're also providing this early indication of our expectations for 2015, in lieu of more specific detail on the financial impact of the new Lowe's paint program. We've been very consistent over the years to not disclose details about any one customer-specific relationship or program, and we intend to maintain that discipline regarding our business relationship with Lowe's. 
For the full year 2014, we expect consolidated net sales will increase approximately 9% compared to full year 2013. With annual sales at that level, we are narrowing our guidance for 2014 diluted net income per common share with a higher-end of our previous range and now expect to be in the range of $8.75 to $8.80 per share, compared to $7.26 per share earned in 2013. This annual guidance includes our expectation that the Comex acquisition will reduce earnings per share by $0.28 per share in 2014. The 2014 annual guidance also includes initial startup expenses related to the HGTV HOME by Sherwin-Williams paint program that were not included in our previous 2014 annual guidance. 
In addition, expenses were incurred in the fourth quarter related to the increasing environmental remediation cost estimates. The paint program startup expenses and environmental cost will slightly exceed the $21 million titanium dioxide settlement we received in the fourth quarter, which was disclosed in Management's Discussion and Analysis in our third quarter 2014 10-Q. These 3 unusual and onetime items in the fourth quarter, essentially cancel each other out, allowing our core operations to drive earning results in the quarter. 
For the full year 2015, we expect consolidated net sales to increase 7% to 11% compared to the full year 2014. With annual sales at that level, we anticipate diluted net income per common share for 2015 will be in the range of $10.65 and $10.85 per share. This 2015 outlook includes our expectation that the HGTV HOME by Sherwin-Williams paint program at Lowe's will increase sales by a low single-digit percentage in the year and have a modestly positive impact on diluted net income per common share in the first year of this program. 
Again, we'd like to thank you, all, for joining us this morning, and we'd be happy to take your questions.

2804211.transcript_text3:
This is actually Matt Krueger sitting in for Ghansham today. Could you expand on the timing of the decision to bring HGTV HOME into Lowe's? Sherwin-Williams retailers have kind of been talking for quite some time now, why it has now worked out?

---

Right. Matt, this announcement today and yesterday has been very consistent with our long-term strategy of pursuing an architectural paint program with a big-box retailer. We are cognizant of the important position that channel owns in the DIY consumer market, and we've long said that we felt we had compelling reasons and programs that could be helpful there, and we're very pleased that we've been able to make that announcement with Lowe's today.

---

Great. Next, as the HGTV HOME brand is already offered through Sherwin-Williams' store network, how much, if any, cannibalization do you expect when HGTV is introduced at Lowe's?

---

We don't expect cannibalization. We think there are fundamental differences between the targeted customers that we serve through our stores into the home centers. There are customers who enjoy that format and that channel. And having our products available to them in that channel, we think, will be beneficial to our efforts there.

---

I was just curious in your 2015 guidance that you're assuming in terms of raw materials. Obviously, since you reported, there has been another big move-down in Brent that could impact your resin costs and then there have been some headlines that maybe TiO2 prices are going to move lower into next year. So what do assume year over year?

---

This is Bob Wells. Obviously, we did make a call on raw materials in these numbers, but we're providing this sales and outlook for 2015 more to help you frame how the Lowe's program and these various other moving parts are going to affect our results. 2819118.eventHeadline: Prudential Financial, Inc., 2015 Guidance/Update Call, Dec 11, 2014
2819118.transcript_text1:
Thank you, Cynthia. Good morning, and thank you for joining our 2015 financial outlook conference call. Please find our presentation for today's call on our website at www.investor.prudential.com. Representing Prudential in today's call are: John Strangfeld, CEO; Mark Grier, Vice Chairman; Charlie Lowrey, Head of International Business; Steve Pelletier, Head of Domestic Businesses; Rob Falzon, Chief Financial Officer; and Rob Axel, Principal Accounting Officer. We will start with prepared comments by John and Rob, and then we will answer your questions.
Before we begin, please take a look at the slides in the deck that cover forward-looking statements and the non-GAAP measure adjusted operating income. And with that, I will hand it over to John.

---

Thank you, Mark. Welcome, everyone, to our 2015 financial outlook presentation. We've chosen this timing a little later than a year ago to enable us to use more current information as we set expectations for the coming year. I will make some opening remarks, hand it over to Rob to walk through the assumptions and factors influencing our 2015 guidance, and then, we'll follow up with concluding comments.
I'll begin on Slide 2. We remain optimistic about our prospects for 2015 and beyond. Our financial strength and capital flexibility, combined with an attractive mix of businesses and strong execution, have enabled us to deliver a return on equity well in excess of industry averages. We've capitalized on organic growth opportunities and supplemented them with good acquisitions that have been effectively integrated. At the same time, we have returned capital to shareholders in a disciplined manner. Share repurchases have exceeded $3 billion since we reinstated our share repurchase program in 2011. And we have steadily increased our dividend from $1.45 in 2011 to an annualized rate of $2.32 presently. Looking forward, we expect increased capital flexibility. The transactions we announced last week to repurchase our Class B shares and redeem the IHC debt of the Closed Block business will simplify our business structure and enhance our financial flexibility. Furthermore, we expect to convert a higher percentage of adjusted operating income into deployable capital. Overall, we are pleased with the positioning of our businesses. And while we can't predict with certainty how markets will evolve or future changes in the competitive landscape, we are confident that the investments we continue to make in our people and businesses will enable us to remain well positioned to deliver value to our stakeholders and customers.
Turning to Slide 3. As you see, our return on equity has increased from about 10% in 2009 and 2010 to over 15% since 2013. This improvement has been driven by a combination of good execution in our core businesses, favorable markets and investment results, as well as effective capital deployment. And while much of the improvement has been driven by factors we believe are sustainable, we have also benefited from tailwinds that cannot be assumed to recur, as Rob will discuss. We continue to believe a 13% to 14% long-term ROE objective is appropriate given our mix of businesses and growth prospects. It is an objective that we set to achieve across the cycle and is set at a level that enables us to invest appropriately in our businesses and infrastructure to facilitate longer-term growth. It also enables us the latitude to capitalize on very good opportunities that might be lower risk yet create attractive value for shareholders that we might otherwise avoid if we were committed to meeting a higher ROE objective.
With that as the opening, I'll now hand it over to Rob Falzon. Rob?

---

Thanks, John. As you've just seen, our results for the first 9 months of this year, as measured by ROE, have been stronger than our long-term objective over a cycle. Many of the items that can affect our reported results in either direction were on the plus side in 2014. I'll true you the major tailwinds and headwinds that have played into our results and how we are thinking about some of those items that can affect the comparison of results going into 2015. The strong U.S. equity markets in 2014 have exceeded our modeled expectations of 6% appreciation and have bolstered the growth of our account values and assets under management, driving higher fees, lower costs of our guaranteed benefits and more favorable amortization factors. As we've called out during each of the first 3 quarters, higher-than-expected returns on non-coupon investments have also contributed to our results, especially in the Retirement business. In addition, we've benefited from more favorable mortality than our average expectations, both in U.S. Individual Life and International Insurance, and from strong Retirement case experience. These tailwinds were partly offset by the impact of sustained low interest rates during 2014. Going into 2015, we are assuming a return to average expectations of the items we've identified as tailwinds for 2014, producing a headwind in the comparison of results. Low interest rates are expected to remain a factor. While we are assuming a modest increase in U.S. interest rates over the course of the year, we expect to continue to reinvest at rates below the yields of general account investments that are rolling off. We are hedging the yen at JPY 91 to the dollar for 2015 compared to JPY 82 for 2014, representing a headwind in the comparison for the nearly half of our earnings in Japan that are yen denominated. And we expect to ramp up investing in technology systems and infrastructure across our businesses. While this impacts our results, we believe these efforts will enhance our competitiveness, lead to operating efficiencies going forward and enable us to be more responsive to enhanced regulatory oversight. We expect to benefit from greater financial flexibility in the coming year, which, over time, should help mitigate the headwinds in the comparison of results that we've identified. Our business momentum is driving solid capital generation. And as John mentioned, we expect a growing proportion of our earnings to translate into capital available for deployment. In addition, the restructuring of the Closed Block business that we announced last week will add to our financial flexibility by freeing up, for general corporate purposes, funds that were essentially trapped in Prudential Insurance.
Now let's move to our earnings guidance for 2015. Turning to Slide 5. Here are some of the key assumptions and considerations that underpin our guidance. Our guidance assumes a 2014 year-end S&P 500 level of 2,020, growing at 6% over the year and ending next year at 2,144. Our International Insurance non-U.S. dollar earnings are fully hedged for 2015 at JPY 91 and KRW 1,120 per dollar. Our interest rate assumptions are based on an averaging of observed forward yield curves. As a benchmark, the 10-year Treasury rate increases just under 3% by the end of 2015. We are expecting an effective tax rate of approximately 27%. We expect our capital deployment to be supported by an increasing ratio of cash flow to adjusted operating income. To be more specific, we are now expecting that about 60% of our after-tax adjusted operating income will become available for deployment over and above the organic growth needs of our businesses. This is an increase from the roughly 50% level that we have experienced historically. This ratio may vary from one year to another, and it is an expectation of an average over a multiyear period. It assumes that AOI and net income generally converge over time. In addition, we expect greater flexibility in terms of readily deployable capital due to our Closed Block business restructuring, which I'll discuss in a moment. Finally, our year-end leverage ratio based on capital debt is expected to be within our 25% target.
Slide 6 walks through our earnings guidance. First, to level set. For the first 9 months of 2014, our earnings per share, excluding items we've identified as market-driven and discrete, was $7.51. Recall that throughout the first 3 quarters, as we've discussed our results, we've called out additional items that tend to fluctuate and were, in the aggregate, tailwinds, as mentioned earlier. Adjusting for the non-run rate items we called out, including favorable mortality and excess non-coupon investment income, as well as similar items that were not significant in any individual quarter but still impact year-to-date results, provides an annualized run rate of $9.25. This simple annualization doesn't fully reflect the inherent quarterly variability in our results and should not be viewed as a projection of our 2014 results. However, we believe this view provides a useful baseline for discussing our 2015 guidance. Starting from this $9.25 annualized baseline, we take into account market factors such as our 6% U.S. equity market growth assumption and the interest rate assumptions that I mentioned earlier. We expect continued fundamental growth in our businesses, including the contribution of several significant pension risk transfer transactions that came onboard in the Retirement business late in 2014. And we expect to benefit from deployment of excess capital in ways that are accretive to our results, including the midyear acquisition of an ownership position in a leading Chilean pension provider that we announced in October. As in the past, we expect to balance our usage of capital between deployment in our businesses based on market opportunities and return to our shareholders. Putting all this together, our 2015 earnings guidance range for baseline adjusted operating income is $9.60 to $10.10 per share.
Turning to Slide 7. Earlier, we talked about headwinds and tailwinds, including equity markets and interest rates. On this slide, you can see the estimated impact to our earnings per share from a plus or minus 10% movement in the equity markets and a plus or minus 100 basis point change in interest rates, assumed in each case to occur at the beginning of 2015 and viewed in isolation. As shown, a 10% move in the equity markets translates to about $0.30 per share in our results, while a 100 basis point change in interest rates, defined as a parallel shift of the yield curve, is worth about $0.20 per share for 2015. I would like to caution that these sensitivities are not necessarily linear and not entirely symmetrical and should not be extrapolated over more severe shock levels in either direction. Nonetheless, they should provide a useful framework to help understand the direction and order of magnitude of 2 of the more important macro assumptions that affect our businesses.
Now taking a look at our estimated year-end capital position on Slide 8. We calculate our on balance sheet capital capacity by comparing the statutory capital position of Prudential Insurance to our 400% RBC ratio target and then adding capital capacity held at the parent company and other subsidiaries. Our year-end 2014 estimate of our capital position gives effect, on a pro forma basis, for the Closed Block restructuring transactions that are expected to close at the beginning of January, as well as the business-as-usual activity we expect during the fourth quarter. When we announced the Closed Block restructuring, we indicated our expectation that the transactions would reduce overall on balance sheet capital capacity because we were using a portion of the surplus and related assets resident in Prudential Insurance to redeem both the IHC debt and the Class B Stock that are supported by those assets. We also indicated that we would see an increase in readily deployable capital because the excess of the surplus and related assets over the cost to redeem those 2 securities becomes available for general corporate purposes. As we reported in our 8-K, the amounts required to redeem the IHC debt and repurchase the Class B Stock total about $2.8 billion or approximately $2.6 billion after taking effect of the make whole pay -- the tax effect of the make whole payments on the debt. The redemptions will be funded by a $2 billion dividend from Prudential Insurance, for which we received approval from the regulators, and by funds available within the intermediate holding company that are not included in the capital position of Prudential Insurance. When we factor in normal fourth quarter activity, the net result is a reduction from about $5 billion of overall on balance sheet capital capacity that we reported as of September 30 to roughly $3.5 billion, as you see here, before our funding of the AFP Habitat Chilean joint venture that is expected to close during 2015. Of the $3.5 billion, we would consider about $3 billion to be readily deployable, an increase of $1.5 billion from September 30. We will continue to manage Prudential Insurance to a capital level that we believe is consistent with AA ratings objectives and estimate that, as of year end, its RBC will exceed our 400% target after giving effect to the Closed Block restructuring. In addition, our capital position assumes a debt-to-capital ratio consistent with our 25% target.
Finally, in Japan, Prudential of Japan and Gibraltar Life are also expected to continue to report strong solvency margins well above our targets.
I'll now turn it back over to John.

---

Thank you, Rob. To conclude, on Slide 9. Our expectations for a solid 2015 are led by an attractive business mix and favorable underlying fundamentals that we expect to produce solid baseline earnings per share growth, even if we do not experience the same positive tailwinds we've seen over the last couple of years. And likewise, we believe our business mix and disciplined capital deployment will enable us to produce a return on equity across the cycle of 13% to 14%, representing a healthy premium to industry averages and our cost of equity. Additionally, our capital flexibility is increasing. The Closed Block restructuring adds to our readily deployable capital. And going forward, we expect more of our adjusted operating income to be available to deploy towards outsized organic growth, M&A or capital return.
With that, I'll turn it back to the operator so we can take your questions.

【回答: Robert Falzon (Executives)】
Tom, it's Rob. I would probably just jump in and add just a couple of thoughts, which is that we don't provide segment-level guidance, but I think you could expect to see a continuation of the recent themes that you've seen in our businesses. We benefit from core organic growth in our Insurance businesses and our Asset Management businesses, while some of our other businesses, like Retirement, can be a little bit more episodic. But as John indicated, we see core growth at a fundamental level across our businesses.

---

【質問: Thomas Gallagher (Analysts)】
Got you. And then just one follow-up overall. And this -- I guess this is a bit of a broader question specific to Japan. I think there's been a considerable increase in concerns over the market becoming a lot more competitive and that it's pressuring both margins and growth for that business for most of the non-Japanese companies that operate over there. Can you talk about whether that's a trend that you're seeing and if that's embedded in your guidance? Or you're not seeing that impact?

---

【回答: Charles Lowrey (Executives)】
Sure. Tom, this is Charlie. At the risk of seeming a little overly optimistic or naïve, we think our business model will hold. So let me take a little while and explain why. And if we take a step back, we've been in Japan for 25 years. And we've really focused on 3 key aspects of our business. The first, of course, is proprietary distribution. And through that distribution, we've focused on needs-based selling. And by virtue of that, we've focused on the third component, which is Death Protection. And the result's been the creation of an earnings stream comprised mainly of M&E margins or insurance margins and not of investment margin, specifically because we focus on Death Protection and not savings products. And that's led to steady growth and low volatility over about -- over the 25 years we've been there, through the lost decade of stagnation and deflation, through earthquakes and tsunamis, even a nuclear meltdown but, as importantly, through the ups and downs of the yen-dollar rate. So the yen was $1.23, and we tend to forget this, in August 2007 and has gone up and down and was going up and down before that. So you can contrast this to other firms that use either part-time or third-party sales forces selling savings products or third-sector products. And then sales have gotten harder, you're right. Some of these firms are looking outside of Japan. But our strategy couldn't be more different. And it really focuses on proprietary distribution, and that started with the LP model long ago. We expanded that into middle market and affinity groups. And don't forget that the Teachers' group represents 25% of Gibraltar sales, and that's not going away anytime soon. And that enables us to maintain healthy margins as we go forward. The second aspect is, as we did get into some third-party distribution, we did it within a proprietary fashion. So banks have secondees, which are proprietary to us, and we really started that model. And now, with the IA channel, we have proprietary wholesalers. And these 2 channels are additive to us. We're not dependent upon them. They represent maybe 1/3 of our sales, so most of our sales are still from proprietary distribution. So the question is, then, how do we continue to grow in Japan's current economic condition? And I think there are three ways, as we think about it. The first, obviously, is the normal LP and Life Consultant growth. And we've seen some of that growth in both systems. The second, we flagged the inheritance market during our investor call -- or our Investor Day, and we're conducting specific training in both Prudential Japan and Gibraltar to take advantage of this when it -- when the tax rates go up at the beginning of next year. And the third is by increasing our penetration in the third-party distribution markets: one, by the number of agents selling within the institutions by whom we have relationships; and the second is by the number of type of products offered. And we're beginning to make real headway with recurring premium insurance products. So is it easy? Absolutely not. We have a bunch of headwinds. And as we said on Investor Day, we won't enjoy some of the tailwinds. But is this what we've been doing for 25 years? You bet. And that's why we think the business model will hold because, while we are changing and adapting to the market and with the market, we're also holding on to the core attributes of what we think is a non-replicable model that provides us with a sustainable competitive advantage going forward.

---

【回答: Robert Falzon (Executives)】
And Tom, it's Rob again. Let me jump in and just finish off the Japan story with sort of 2 other observations. The first is, you asked about the value of our hedges earlier. And let me give a sort of a more complete view of that because I think it's important to understand how we're managing that FX risk that we have in the form of our concentration of earnings in yen. First, recall that less than half the earnings are actually yen denominated. We have U.S. dollar and Aussie dollar-related earnings in that business. And our expenses are all yen based, so it means that our earnings coming out of that are less than you might otherwise think in terms of yen exposure. But importantly, we have the income hedge, and I know the market is generally very familiar with that. It's a rolling 3-year income hedge. And we've married that with an equity hedge, the notional value of which is about $14 billion. And the overall theory is that, that hedge generates assets in a yen weakening environment that can be deployed to mitigate the earnings and ROE impacts of that depreciation of the yen. And we, in fact, calibrate the equity hedge that -- such that, in conjunction with our income hedges, it achieves that outcome. So that $14 billion that has $1.1 billion of unrealized gains in it, those gains, as they're realized, as they settle, become available for us to invest at a return, which will allow us to replace the earnings that we've lost by virtue of the depreciation in the yen. And we think that, that will work effectively to the benefit of shareholders going forward to mitigate any yen exposure that we've got. The second thing I want to highlight is that we've undertaken some structural changes within our Japan operations that will largely mitigate the GAAP-driven volatility in net income and book value from FX remeasurement on a go-forward basis but commencing in the first quarter of 2015. So we will have a noisy fourth quarter by virtue of the ongoing depreciation of the yen, but that restructuring will then substantially mitigate that beginning in 2015.

---

【質問: Thomas Gallagher (Analysts)】
That was helpful from both Charlie and Rob. Just one last quick follow-up. Rob, what are -- this capital hedge, how long has this been in place for? And have you significantly grown or reduced it in size in response to the recent movement in changes in currency?

---

【回答: Robert Falzon (Executives)】
So the hedge has been in place for several years. I want to say it goes back to 2000 -- earlier than 2010. I don't remember when we first began -- Mark -- it was a lot earlier.

---

【回答: Mark Grier (Executives)】
It was a different policy approach, but we've had a structural short yen on the balance sheet, meaning U.S. dollars in assets funded with yen liabilities. And that actually goes back to more like 2003.

---

【回答: Robert Falzon (Executives)】
Thank you. What happened in around 2010 is that we began to calibrate that in a way that we -- that I just described to you, which is we began to be more disciplined around the size of that hedge against the economic value that we were getting out of Japan such that we could replace the ROE and earnings in the way that I just described it. And so the answer to your question is, yes, we're adjusting that all the time to reflect both the change in the yen and the change in the earning -- yen-based earnings that are coming out of our business. And during the course of this year -- or between last year and this year, that has gone up by a couple of billion dollars.

---

【回答: Mark Grier (Executives)】
But maybe just one qualifier. It's not a trading position. So when we talk about current circumstances, we're calibrating and implementing around a more structural theme related to the value of the franchise in Japan as opposed to a view on the yen.

---

【質問: Seth Weiss (Analysts)】
I had a question on the Closed Block restructuring deal, specifically how it may be contributing to next year's EPS. And I guess the way I'm thinking about it is that you highlighted $1.5 billion of greater deployable capital, but I believe that there may be even a greater amount of capital that, while not readily deployable, is now generating earnings for common shareholders that wasn't before a part of the Financial Services business. So maybe if you could help us think about how much that capital position is and how that may be contributing to common shareholders' earnings per share and what type of return you're assuming?

---

【回答: Robert Falzon (Executives)】
Seth, the way I would -- it's Rob again. The way I would characterize it is that the way we described the available capital for the -- coming out of the Closed Block restructuring, there are no sort of other hidden sources of capital. The $3 billion reflects, fully, the readily deployable that comes out of that transaction. That did come both from PICA and from surplus and related assets that we had outside the insurance company, if that's what you might be referring to. So the full benefit has been reflected in our capital capacity and in the readily deployable. The accretion that results from that, which is some combination of reduced costs and earnings on cash, and then -- and that ultimately -- the redeployment of that capital is reflected in the guidance that we've given. And how it is redeployed will influence whether we're at the higher or lower end of that guidance.

---

【質問: Seth Weiss (Analysts)】
Okay. That's helpful. So I suppose my calculations before had been about $2.5 billion of new capital when I think of what was $5.3 billion of statutory resources that I believe were in the Closed Block. And if you subtract out the $2.8 billion that you highlighted, that's how I get to the $2.5 billion. Is that not the right way to think about it?

---

【回答: Robert Falzon (Executives)】
Yes, I think the math that you've done, if you look at sort of the capital capacity, that -- if you follow the math that's outlined in the K, there are really only 2 items that you don't have in order to get you to sort of the right number. So if you think about, we started at about $5 billion of on balance sheet capacity. The uses -- all of the surplus and related, substantially the surplus and related that is -- that is which disclosed in the 8-K, was already in our balance sheet capacity numbers because they were in PICA and they were in our RBC calculations. And so what happens is that $5 billion goes down by the use of proceeds that are articulated in the 8-K, which is about $2.5 billion on an after-tax basis. The 2 pieces that you don't have -- or that there are certain surplus and related assets that were not part of our capital capacity is your question you asked earlier, that's about $0.5 billion or so. That gets freed up and gets added to the capacity. And then you've got another about $0.5 billion that, call it, sort of fourth quarter effects because we're benchmarking this off the third quarter. So the combination of those 2 takes that $2.5 billion down to about $1.5 billion. We started at $5 billion. We wind up at around $3.5 billion. That's the math. Now of the $3.5 billion, we estimate that around $3 billion of that is readily deployable because a substantial portion of the net proceeds from that transaction become readily deployable but not all of it.

---

【質問: Seth Weiss (Analysts)】
Okay, that's helpful. And one very quick follow-up. Just unrelated, you didn't highlight anything on increases to your own pension expenses for next year. I just wanted to verify that there is no headwind from pension expenses for your own obligation.

---

【回答: Robert Falzon (Executives)】
Well, in fact, Seth, they're -- we built it into our guidance, but yes, there were some headwinds from our pension obligation. The new mortalities tables came out that will be used for GAAP purposes, and we will be reflecting those new mortality tables in our pension liability. That will cause the liability to go up. We're estimating -- I don't want to give any precise numbers, but it's somewhere between -- depending on the finalization of those mortality tables and the review of our liability, it's going to be somewhere between 4% and 7% of that liability will go up as a result of that mortality change. And then that will have to be -- that change in that liability will be amortized in over some period of time. But that's been built into our guidance.

---

【質問: Seth Weiss (Analysts)】
Okay. Are you able to help us out in terms of what the EPS impact is there and if it's ongoing or onetime?

---

【回答: Robert Falzon (Executives)】
It is ongoing in the form of amortization. But no, I don't have a specific EPS impact for you on that.

---

【質問: Suneet Kamath (Analysts)】
Just wanted to go back to the readily deployable excess capital and make sure I'm thinking about it correctly. So the starting point is $3 billion. I think you said in the past that you normally like to keep $1.5 billion as a buffer, a cushion. And I think you have roughly $600 million for the Chilean acquisition or Chilean investment, I should say. So that would get me to roughly $900 million of readily deployable that is above and beyond the cushion. Is that the right way to think about that?

---

【回答: Robert Falzon (Executives)】
Suneet, it's Rob again. No, actually, your starting point would not be correct. The $1.5 billion you're thinking about is the minimum cash number, largely backed by capital, that we keep available to handle liquidity issues and potential stresses. That is not included in our capital capacity, that is -- or readily deployable. That is actually deducted out of both those numbers. So when we give you a $3 billion number for readily deployable, it is the amount in excess of the $1.5 billion that you're thinking of.

---

【質問: Suneet Kamath (Analysts)】
Okay. Because I thought, on a prior call, maybe it was Mark said, in normal cases, we like to keep $1.5 billion of -- or we have been running with $1.5 billion of readily deployable. But I guess you're saying that, that's -- I'm mistaken there?

---

【回答: Mark Grier (Executives)】
Well, we have, in the past, generally said that we would typically be above the bare minimum threshold. But the cushion notion that you're talking about is not as rigid as a rule that we're following.

---

【質問: Suneet Kamath (Analysts)】
Okay, got it. And then the second question is on -- I guess, a follow-up to Ryan's question on expenses and the multiyear investments that you're making. I think he had asked if you could help us size it. I don't know if you did. I think you gave us the 3 buckets. But should we think about any of those 3 buckets -- well, first, should we think about it as almost split evenly across those 3 buckets? And is there any one that you think -- any one of those buckets that you think will be just an ongoing cost of business for the foreseeable future?

---

【回答: Robert Falzon (Executives)】
Well, they are multiyear. And so for purposes of, I think, this discussion, we should assume that it will repeat year-to-year. I think, if you're looking for quantums on that, the guidance I can give you, if we compare the level of net spending that we're doing in 2015 against the net spending that we did in 2014, it's an increment of about $0.15 a share if that's helpful.

---

【質問: Suneet Kamath (Analysts)】
Okay, got it. And then just the last definitional question. I mean, I think a lot of these life insurance companies talk about cash flow a little bit differently. So when you're giving us this 60% long-term average as a percentage of operating income, is that before or after holding company expenses, including the dividend?

---

【回答: Robert Falzon (Executives)】
After.

---

【質問: Suneet Kamath (Analysts)】
So that's after interest expense and dividends?

---

【回答: Robert Falzon (Executives)】
Correct.

B3WS2X9.eventHeadline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2014
B3WS2X9.transcript_text1:
Thank you, operator, and good afternoon, everyone. Joining me today are Hock Tan, President and CEO; and Tony Maslowski, Chief Financial Officer of Avago Technologies.
After the market closed today, Avago distributed a press release and financial tables describing our financial performance for the fourth quarter and fiscal year 2014. If you did not receive a copy, you may obtain the information from the Investors section of Avago's website at www.avagotech.com.
This conference call is being webcast live, and a recording will be available via telephone playback for 1 week. It will also be archived in the Investors section of our website at avagotech.com.
During the prepared comments section of this call, Hock and Tony will be providing details of our fourth fiscal quarter and fiscal year 2014 results, background to our first fiscal quarter 2015 outlook and some commentary regarding the business environment. We will take questions after the end of our prepared comments.
In addition to U.S. GAAP reporting, Avago reports certain financial measures on a non-GAAP basis. A reconciliation between GAAP and non-GAAP measures is included in the tables attached to today's press release. Comments made during today's call will primarily refer to our non-GAAP financial results. Please refer to our press release today and our recent filings with the SEC for information on the specific risk factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially from the forward-looking statements made on this call.
At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Hock Tan. Hock?

---

Thank you, Ashish, and good afternoon, everyone. Thanks for joining us. We are going to start today by reviewing recent business highlights and then Tony will provide a summary of our fourth quarter and fiscal 2014 financial results.
So revenue for our fourth quarter was $1.61 billion, an increase of 25% from the prior quarter. The sequential revenue increase was above the upper end of our guidance, which was 18% to 22%. Wireless growth was better than expectations with revenue growing 73% sequentially, driven largely by product ramp of a new smartphone generation at a large OEM. Enterprise Storage also performed significantly better than expected even without considering contribution from our recent acquisition, PLX.
Now before I provide more color on each of our segments, let me quickly provide a short update on the integration of the Avago and LSI operations. As you know, we have completed the sale of 2 non-core businesses, the LSI flash and Axxia businesses, which had annualized operating spend of approximately $200 million. This has been a key contributor to the significant improvement in our operating model. We have also made great progress in extracting synergies from integrating LSI onto the Avago platform. We are now more than halfway through this process and expect to complete the balance of the integration program as we exit our fiscal 2015. Clearly, the financial benefits from the integration program and the divestiture of non-core businesses have been achieved faster than we had originally planned and has definitely given us flexibility to step up R&D investments in certain core businesses.
Now turning to the discussion of our various segments, starting with Wireless. In the fourth quarter, revenue from Wireless was much better than expectations said earlier, growing 73% sequentially. Wireless represented 39% of our total revenue from continuing operations. And on a year-on-year basis, grew 83%. Within the quarter, growth was largely driven by the ramp of a new smartphone generation at the north -- at a large North American smartphone OEM. We also benefited in this from a significant increase in our content.
We also saw strong double-digit sequential revenue growth from our FBAR-related products across the board and, in particular, from multiple Chinese LTE smartphone OEMs. In fact, over 80% of our Wireless revenue is now FBAR-related, which has driven significant improvements in Wireless gross margins.
Not surprisingly though, we continue to be very capacity constrained even as we have been investing in additional capacity to meet demand. Looking towards first quarter fiscal 2015, we expect sustained demand from our large North American smartphone OEM to mostly offset broad-based seasonal declines from many other global handset OEMs. We're not sure how this will play out in the quarter, so for now we expect Wireless revenue in Q1 fiscal '15 to be flat to perhaps slightly down on a sequential basis.
Moving to Wired Infrastructure, which consists of our SerDes-based ASIC business and our fiber optics business. Here, the Wired segment performed close to expectation in the fourth quarter, with revenue growing 1% sequentially. Wired revenue represented 22% of our total revenue from continuing operations. You may recall, we saw very significant strength in our ASIC business in the third quarter and that strength sustained into this fourth quarter. Overall, ASIC revenue was fairly flat on a sequential basis, with growth in Ethernet switching and routing products largely offset by declines in base station and high-performance computing.
In fiber optics, we grew moderately from the prior quarter, in particular, with very strong shipments of our 40G -- 40 gigabit, I should say, BiDi fiber products as the customer, the exclusive customer, built up their supply chain to support their new product launch. We also benefited from stronger demand for 16G fibre channel transceivers in storage markets and very strong Fiber to the Home deployment in China. Against this, we see declines in 10 gigabit and other standard transceivers.
Looking forward to first quarter 2015, we expect growth in our ASIC business to resume, partially offset by softness in our fiber optics business. In ASICs, we expect a strong ramp of next-generation LTE base station ASIC at a large Chinese OEM. And we expect a stable enterprise and data center Ethernet switching market. However, in fiber optics, we expect recovery in parallel optic shipments into routers, core routers, to be more than offset, however, by declines from our other Ethernet transceiver products, especially as 40G takes a pause. As a result, we do expect low-single digit sequential revenue growth for our Wired segment.
On to Enterprise Storage. Here, in this segment, our Enterprise segment -- our Enterprise Storage products include our hard disk drive business and our server and storage connectivity product lines. Starting this fourth quarter, this segment will also include products from our recent PLX acquisitions, which will be part of our server and storage connectivity business. In this fourth quarter, Enterprise Storage revenue, including contribution from PLX, came in stronger than expected and grew 15% sequentially. To provide you with some continuity from the prior quarter, Enterprise Storage revenue without PLX grew 8% sequentially. This segment represented 29% of our total revenues from continuing operations. The HDD or hard disk drive end market had a seasonally strong quarter, with a large increase in Enterprise shipments and our HDD revenue grew mid-single digit sequentially on a percentage basis.
In server and storage connectivity, we also had a very strong fourth quarter with revenue growing double digits sequentially on a percentage basis. This growth was driven by our server customers staging supply lines in anticipation of a strong tri-annually-driven server refresh cycle, and they accordingly purchased significantly high amount of our 12G SAS and RAID solutions this quarter.
Looking forward to Q1 fiscal '15, we expect data center and enterprise demand to continue driving growth in server and storage connectivity business. We also expect this similar trend to also drive growth in our HDD business. As a result, we expect mid-single digit sequential revenue growth for our Enterprise Storage business.
Finally, moving on to Industrial. Fourth quarter, our Industrial segment performed below expectation with revenue declining by 2% sequentially. Industrial represented 10% of our total revenues from continuing operations. Resales were weaker here than expected in all regions except the Americas, as we saw a cautionary stance from customers in those various other countries. On a sequential basis, in fact, resales in America were up 2%, but declined 9% in Asia-Pacific, 6% in Europe and 13% in Japan. Regardless, our industrial product inventory at our distributors remain very tight. In Q4, we were also expecting some revenue related to a last-time purchase for a legacy program which is now expected to push out to the first fiscal quarter.
And looking into the first quarter fiscal of 2015, we expect mid-single-digit decline on a percentage basis in Industrial product revenue due to planned customer shutdowns late half of December. But to be -- however, this we expect to be more than offset by the anticipated last-time buy I referenced earlier. As a result, we expect low- to mid-single digit sequential growth on a percentage basis for Industrial segment.
So in summary, for Q4 and for fiscal 2015, we have a very strong finish with 25% sequential revenue growth in the fourth quarter, driven by strong growth in Wireless, robust demand in Enterprise Storage, flattish Wired and a small decline in Industrial. For our first fiscal quarter 2015, we are expecting mid-single-digit growth in Enterprise Storage, low- to mid-single-digit growth in Industrial. However, low growth -- low-single-digit growth in Wired, offset by a flat to down Wireless segment. As a result, we expect consolidated revenue growth in the low-single digit sequential growth -- sequentially on a percentage basis.
With that, let me now turn the call over to Tony for a more detailed review of our fourth quarter and fiscal 2014 financials.

---

Thank you, Hock, and good afternoon, everyone. Before reviewing the fourth quarter and fiscal 2014 financial results, I want to remind you that my comments today will focus primarily on our non-GAAP results from continuing operations unless otherwise specifically noted. A reconciliation of our GAAP and non-GAAP data is included with the earnings release issued today and is also available on our website at www.avagotech.com.
In prior quarters, we have provided revenue results for our 4 target markets, Wireless, Enterprise Storage, Wired Infrastructure and Industrial & Other. Starting with this quarter and going forward, these 4 target markets will become our reportable segments, aligning our financial reporting with how our management views the business. We will provide certain segment-level results in our SEC filings starting with our upcoming Form 10-K. The business composition of our reportable segments remains the same as previously defined target markets. Please note that our fourth quarter results include contributions from the PLX acquisition, which closed on August 12, 2014.
Revenue of $1.61 billion in the fourth quarter represents an increase of 25% from the prior quarter and came in higher than the upper end of our guidance. Revenue from our Wireless and Enterprise Storage segments came in better than our expectations. The Wired segment performed close to expectations, and we saw weaker-than-expected revenue from the Industrial & Other segment.
Foxconn was a greater than 10% customer in the fourth fiscal quarter. Our fourth quarter gross margin from continuing operations was 58%, which was above our guidance range of 55% to 57%, primarily due to better revenue mix and fab utilization.
Turning to operating expenses. R&D expenses were $214 million and SG&A expenses were $89 million, driving total operating expenses for Q4 to $303 million, $4 million below guidance, primarily because of some anticipated spending in R&D, which is not expected in the first quarter. As a percentage of sales, R&D was 13% and SG&A was 6% of net revenue, respectively.
Income from operations for the quarter was $636 million and represented 40% of net revenue. Taxes came in at $42 million for the fourth quarter, $4 million above our guidance. This was primarily due to higher income than forecast. Fourth quarter net income was $556 million and earnings per diluted share were $1.99.
Fourth quarter interest expense was $54 million. The other income and expense line was $16 million, resulting primarily from gains on the sale of non-core LSI portfolio investments, which had a positive impact on EPS.
Our share-based compensation in the fourth quarter was $49 million. The breakdown of the expense for the fourth quarter include $6 million in cost of goods sold, $19 million in R&D and $24 million in SG&A. In the first quarter fiscal 2015, we anticipate share-based compensation will be approximately $51 million.
Just as a reminder, our definition of non-GAAP net income excludes share-based compensation expense.
Moving on to the balance sheet. Our days sales outstanding were 42 days, an increase from the prior quarter's 39 days, primarily due to linearity of revenue during the quarter. Our inventory ended at $519 million. Days on hand were 70 days, which decreased 9 days from the third quarter as we reduced inventory in our Wireless segment, which had built up in prior quarters to support the strong ramp in fourth quarter shipment.
We ended the quarter with a cash balance of $1.6 billion, and we generated $381 million in operational cash flow. As a reminder, in the fourth quarter, we closed the PLX acquisition, which consumed approximately $308 million in cash, and we closed the sale of our flash business for which we received approximately $450 million in cash. On November 18, 2014, in our first fiscal quarter of 2015, we also closed the sale of the Axxia business and received approximately $650 million in cash.
In the fourth quarter, we spent $189 million on capital expenditures. For the full year fiscal 2015, we expect CapEx to be approximately $600 million, of which approximately $200 million is expected to occur in the first quarter. As a reminder, our first quarter is generally a weaker quarter for cash generation due to the payment of our annual employee bonuses related to the prior fiscal year.
As you may recall, last quarter, we mentioned our intent to use a significant amount of our net proceeds from the sales of the flash and Axxia businesses towards paying down a portion of our outstanding term loan before the end of this calendar year. We are still evaluating our capital needs over the next 12 months and, for now, we see investment of these proceeds in the business as a better short-term use of our cash, including potential investment in our internal fab capacity to support continued demand for our Wireless products.
On September 30, 2014, we paid a quarterly cash dividend of $0.32 per ordinary share, which consumed $81 million of cash. This dividend was raised by $0.03 from the prior quarters. Since the inception of our dividend program in the second quarter of 2011. To-date, our financial performance has allowed us to increase our dividend each quarter. As a reminder, our board reviews and determines our dividend policy on a quarterly basis, based on our financial performance and condition, the contractual provisions related to our outstanding indebtedness and other factors deemed relevant by our board. During the quarter, we did not repurchase any shares.
Now let me briefly recap our fiscal 2014 full year results. Net revenues increased by 71% year-over-year to $4.3 billion, benefiting primarily from 2 quarters of contributions from continuing operations of the LSI businesses as well as strength in our Wireless business. Gross margin increased by 5% year-over-year to 56%, driven by an improvement in product mix, with higher contributions from our FBAR-related wireless products in the classic Avago side, as well as comparatively higher gross margins from the LSI continuing operations. Net income for 2014 increased to $1.343 billion or $4.90 per diluted share as compared to $731 million or $2.89 per diluted share in fiscal 2013.
Now let me turn to our non-GAAP guidance for the first quarter of 2015. This guidance reflects our current assessment of business conditions, and we do not intend to update this guidance. This guidance is for results from continuing operations only.
Net revenue is expected to be flat to up 4% from the fourth quarter. Gross margin is expected to be 57.5%, plus or minus 1 percentage point. Operating expenses are estimated to be approximately $301 million. Taxes are forecasted to be approximately $38 million. Net interest expense and other is expected to be approximately $56 million. And finally, the diluted share count forecast is for 283 million shares.
That concludes my prepared remark. Operator, please open the call for questions.

I was wondering if you could just comment on the Wireless business. You were looking for a very -- a flat guidance. You saw flat guidance last year. And the content in every smartphone will have to increase. And so RF components, as we all know, and has been evident the last 12 months, RF component demand has been very strong. And even within RF components, filter demand is particularly strong because while in semiconductor processes or in semiconductor typical trend, you can -- you do -- you can and do integrate chips functionality together. For instance, multiple -- one power amplifier can support multiple modes, multiple bands. In filters, you only -- you need one separate filter for every single band. B42BPG9.transcript_text1:
Thank you, and good morning, everybody. We appreciate you joining us today to discuss our outlook for 2014 and our initial guidance for 2015. Before we begin, I would like to remind you of our cautionary statements.
This call will contain forward-looking management comments and other statements, reflecting our outlook for future periods. These comments should be considered in conjunction with the cautionary language contained in this morning's release, as well as the detailed cautionary statements found in our most recent annual report on Form 10-K and subsequent SEC filings. A copy of this information is available on our website at www.cokecce.com.
This morning's prepared remarks will be made by John Brock, our CEO; and Nik Jhangiani, our CFO. Hubert Patricot, President of our European Group, is also with us on the call this morning. Following prepared remarks, we will open the call for your questions.
[Operator Instructions] Now I'll turn the call over to John Brock.

---

Thank you, Thor. And we welcome each of you to our business update, as we discuss our expectations for full year 2014 and our outlook for 2015. Joining me today are Nik Jhangiani, our Chief Financial Officer; and Hubert Patricot, President of our European Group. As you know, throughout the year, we have faced a combination of challenges, including persistent macroeconomic softness and evolving customer landscape and consumer sector and a dynamic competitive environment. These factors have limited our results for 2014 and are expected to continue to impact our results next year. As always, we will continue to focus on efficiency, effectiveness and execution, as we manage each element of our business, our brands, customer service, costs, operating expenses and our balance sheet, all with the goal of reigniting top and bottom line growth, and ultimately, delivering value for our shareowners. A key element of our work is day-to-day executional excellence, an area we continue to focus on at every level of our business, as we support some of the world's most popular brands and meet the evolving needs of our customers and our consumers. 
Our portfolio, anchored by our flagship, Coca-Cola trademark brand, includes innovative new products and packages such as Coca-Cola Life, Finley and smartwater, as well as numerous new packages and multi-pack combinations. This type of product and package innovation is essential, as we work to return our company to sustained topline growth. 
We also remain focused on cash generation, as well as the optimization of our capital structure to continue to return cash to shareowners and to drive shareowner value. Since the creation of CCE 4 years ago, we have returned approximately $8 billion to shareowners through share repurchase and dividends, including over $1.1 billion by the end of 2014. We have committed to continue this focus and expect to return at least $850 million to shareowners in 2015 through a combination of share repurchase and dividends. This would represent approximately 8% of our recent market capitalization. As we work to deliver our long-term commitment to shareowner value, we will continue to gauge each business decision, including merger and acquisition opportunities by the value it would create for our shareowners.
Now let's review our outlook for full year 2014. We continue to expect comparable and currency neutral earnings per diluted share growth of approximately 10%. Based on recent rates, currency translation would benefit full year 2014 earnings per diluted share by approximately 3%. We continue to expect net sales for 2014 to be essentially flat, with low single-digit operating income growth, both on a currency, neutral and comparable basis. 
Looking forward to 2015, we expect earnings per diluted share to grow in a range of 6% to 8% on a comparable and currency neutral basis. We expect both net sales and operating income to be slightly positive, both, again, on a comparable and currency neutral basis. 【回答: Hubert Patricot (Executives)】
Yes, retail environment, overall, I guess the economy is slightly improving. 【回答: John Brock (Executives)】

【回答: Hubert Patricot (Executives)】

【質問: Kevin Grundy (Analysts)】
Okay. All right, that's helpful. And then with respect to the spending behind price. 【回答: John Brock (Executives)】

【回答: Hubert Patricot (Executives)】

【回答: Manik Jhangiani (Executives)】
And technically, I would just characterize our guidance is it's really what we would, for a lack of better word, just say middle-of-the-road. 【回答: Hubert Patricot (Executives)】

【回答: Manik Jhangiani (Executives)】

【質問: Ali Dibadj (Analysts)】
And so what timing does it usually come in? What timing should we think about hearing more from you?

---

【回答: Manik Jhangiani (Executives)】

【回答: John Brock (Executives)】
Just prepare a few comments on category.

---

【回答: Hubert Patricot (Executives)】
Yes, John, just to clarify, there are some -- the figures we shared were the figures for the category, and what we said is that the year-to-date figures, which are roughly 1% in volume, 1.3% in value, we see this continuing into next year.

---

【質問: John Faucher (Analysts)】
Okay. And is that what the category is doing right now? Is that a good number for the fourth quarter from a category standpoint, not you guys?

---

【回答: Hubert Patricot (Executives)】
There is some variation in the fourth quarter, but overall, the picture is not so much different.

---

【回答: John Brock (Executives)】
And on share repurchase?

---

【回答: Manik Jhangiani (Executives)】
Sure. 【回答: John Brock (Executives)】
Okay, operator, we have time for one more question.

【回答: John Brock (Executives)】
Let me just make a general comment that immediate consumption has been an area that we wanted to grow, and has been focusing on for a number of years, so a continued emphasis in 2015. ---

【回答: Hubert Patricot (Executives)】
I think that's always been a focus for us. B4TP9G2.transcript_text1:
Thank you, operator. A very eloquent operator today, and good morning, everyone. This morning, we reported financial and operating results for the third quarter of fiscal year 2015. We are very pleased with the strong same-store sales and strong financial and operating results. I will let Michael provide you with the details relating to the financial results and our operating initiatives for the quarter. 
From my perspective, this quarter was defined by strong same-store sales of 5.9% as we increased the number of transactions by 1.1% in the stores and benefited from the growing demand for our higher-priced point items, as evidenced by the 4.8% increase in the average basket size. 
Overall, we're very satisfied with our current price mix, as it continues to stimulate sales and drive traffic to our stores. Our sales this quarter were fueled also by very strong Halloween season sales, as our customers responded positively to our compelling range of Halloween products. The Halloween season was also benefited by -- from ideal sales conditions, including the fact that weather was very favorable compared to the prior year and the fact that Halloween fell on a Friday.
Our sales also continued to rise as we grow our business organically through the opening of 11 net new stores across Canada. Although the pace was slightly lower than in recent quarters due to the timing of new store deliveries, you can rest assured that we can still anticipate the opening of 75 to 80 net new stores in fiscal 2015. These stores continue to be opened in quality retail locations across Canada, with the majority of new stores located in Ontario, British Columbia and Alberta, which are markets that continue to be underpenetrated with dollar stores. We continue to focus our efforts on densifying core urban centers in these markets as well as other markets across Canada.
Following the success of the Halloween season, we are now focused on offering a great assortment of -- to our customers for the upcoming Christmas season. Having experienced very challenging weather conditions in December 2013, especially in the 2 weeks leading up to Christmas, we are now hoping that Mother Nature will be more cooperative this year. Let me now turn the call over to Michael. Michael?

---

Thank you, Larry, and good morning, everyone. So during the third quarter, we increased our sales by 12.4% to $588 million from $522.9 million in the prior year. The increase in sales was fueled by the opening of 81 net new stores over the past 12 months and a same-store sales increase of 5.9% over and above a 4.8% increase reported for Q3 in the prior year. Same-store sales increase in Q3 consisted of 4.8% increase in basket size, which reflects the consumer demand for our higher price point items and a 1.1% increase in the number of transactions, which was boosted by strong Halloween sales.
In the third quarter, our gross margin was 36.8% of sales, compared to 37.1% of sales in Q3 last year. This decrease is partly attributable to slightly lower product margins as we absorb some of the cost increases in order to maintain the compelling value of our products. As we stated earlier this year, we have been managing our gross margin by continually reinvesting in the value proposition offered to our customers. We expect this trend to continue as we target a range between 36% and 37% in fiscal 2015 in order to stimulate continued sales growth.
Our Q3 SG&A as a percentage of sales was 17.2% compared to 18.1% last year. This progression is the result of improved labor productivity achieved through initiatives implemented at store level, including refined labor scheduling and reduction of the number of manual inventory counts. We expect the SG&A to be between 17.1% and 17.5% for the full 2015 fiscal year. 
Our depreciation and amortization expense decreased by $2.5 million this year as a result of change in estimated useful life of our leasehold improvements in our store and warehouse equipment that was made effective in the first quarter of fiscal 2015. 
As announced last quarter, the company completed a 2-for-1 share split by way of share dividend paid on November 17, 2014. The share split ensures that our common shares remain accessible to individual shareholders, potentially increasing and broadening our shareholder base and improving market liquidity for our common shares. Note that all share information and earnings per share data reported for the third quarter ended November 2, 2014 have been retrospectively restated to reflect the 2-for-1 share split. 
Our Q3 net earnings increased to $73 million or $0.55 per diluted share, taking into consideration the share split, compared to $61.7 million or $0.43 per diluted share in the third quarter of fiscal 2014. 
During the quarter, we also repurchased for cancellation 1,233,590 shares on a post-split basis under our normal course issuer bid for consideration of $58.4 million at a weighted average price of $47.32 per common share. 
In terms of our productivity initiatives, we continue to leverage off the benefits of several initiatives rolled out in the stores over the past year, including the Kronos scheduling solution and new point of sales terminal in all of our stores. The Kronos advanced scheduling solution has contributed to the improved labor productivity at store level by more efficiently allocating hours based on the volume and seasonality of sales in each store. This ensures that we have enough employees in stores to handle peak sales period, while reducing hours in lower sales period. 
We are also increasing our reliance on scan data for replenishment purposes, thereby reducing the number of labor hours related to manually -- manual daily counts at store level. 
Additional projects are being evaluated that could further leverage the investments previously made in the stores. This includes the use of new functionalities available on the point-of-sale terminals to streamline the cash management processes and use of the scanning technology to further reduce manual tasks in the store. 
Overall, we are very pleased with the performance of the company this quarter and the progress made on our key initiatives.
This ends our formal remarks, and we can now take questions. So operator, I'll turn the call over to you.

The increase in percentage of items over $1 was obviously the driver of the basket size increase. Just wondering if there were other drivers. Have you seen, for instance, more items in the basket? And -- or has the mix of categories changed in the basket?

---

Not from my perspective. Michael?

---

No. It's -- there's no change, whether in that category or it's higher price point items penetration increase.

---

Okay. And on the gross margin side, given the level of the Canadian dollar and where rents have been trending, do you have a feel for the range of gross margins for next fiscal year? ---

Yes. For the moment, we're -- we still believe it's within 36% to 37%.

---

Yes. I think that in spite of the Canadian dollar, we can manage and give the value we want to give between 36% and 37%.

---

---

Nope.

---

---

Sticking to the drivers of the basket growth, was there a higher number of items at the higher price points? Or really is it sort of the normal maturation process that's just getting better at understanding which products are going to sell through at that price?

Yes. I think I'd agree with that. We're not doing anything special, so our customers seem to be doing that for us.

---

Yes, they are. And just, again, thinking ahead to the Q4 season, if memory serves me correctly, in the past, there is a reasonable proportion of seasonal items that are still at the lower range of those price points in Q4. Are you changing the mix of the Q4 price points for this year?
